prompt:
What is the history of NYC prospect park?

Your entire answer should be wrapped in XML format. You can use HTML tags such as <xml> and </xml> to enclose the XML content.
response:
<xml>
<prospect-park-history>
  <pre-history>
    <indigenous-occupation>For thousands of years, the land that became Prospect Park was inhabited by the Lenape (Delaware) Nation, who used it for hunting, fishing, and gathering, referring to the area as "Mashpee" (land of the great river).</indigenous-occupation>
    <colonial-era>By the 17th century, Dutch settlers established farms on the land, followed by English colonists after the 1664 British takeover of New Netherland. The area remained primarily agricultural until the mid-19th century.</colonial-era>
  </pre-history>
  <planning-and-design>
    <commissioning>In 1865, the Brooklyn Park Commission hired Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux—renowned for designing Manhattan’s Central Park—to create a large public park for Brooklyn’s rapidly growing population.</commissioning>
    <design-philosophy>Olmsted and Vaux aimed to build a "rural escape" distinct from Central Park’s formal elements, prioritizing naturalistic landscapes: rolling meadows, a wooded ravine, and a lake. They intended the park to be a space for all social classes to relax and connect with nature.</design-philosophy>
  </planning-and-design>
  <construction>
    <timeline>
      <partial-opening>Sections of the park, including the Long Meadow and Lake, opened to the public in 1867.</partial-opening>
      <full-completion>The park was fully finished and opened in 1873, after seven years of construction that involved moving over 1.5 million cubic yards of earth, draining marshes, and shaping the terrain.</full-completion>
    </timeline>
    <key-features>
      <long-meadow>A 1.5-mile stretch of unbroken grassland, one of the longest in any U.S. urban park.</long-meadow>
      <ravine>A wooded, stream-fed gorge designed to mimic a natural Appalachian valley.</ravine>
      <lake>A 15-acre body of water for boating and wildlife habitat.</lake>
      <early-menagerie>A small animal collection that evolved into the Prospect Park Zoo.</early-menagerie>
    </key-features>
  </construction>
  <late-19th-to-early-20th-century>
    <popularity>By the late 1800s, Prospect Park became a beloved gathering place, hosting concerts, fairs, and recreational activities. Its carriage drives and paths were frequented by families across all social classes.</popularity>
    <adjacent-developments>
      <lefferts-historic-house>In 1918, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial farmhouse was moved to the park to serve as a rural life museum.</lefferts-historic-house>
      <brooklyn-botanic-garden>Established adjacent to the park in 1910, it became a complementary cultural and educational institution.</brooklyn-botanic-garden>
    </adjacent-developments>
  </late-19th-to-early-20th-century>
  <mid-20th-century-challenges>
    <decline>Mid-century budget cuts, urban neglect, and rising crime led to a period of decline. Many natural features fell into disrepair, and some areas became unsafe for visitors.</decline>
    <wpa-contribution>The Works Progress Administration (WPA) built the Prospect Park Bandshell in 1935, which remains a core venue for outdoor events.</wpa-contribution>
  </mid-20th-century-challenges>
  <restoration-and-revival>
    <prospect-park-alliance>Founded in 1987, this public-private partnership raised millions to restore and maintain the park, reversing decades of neglect.</prospect-park-alliance>
    <key-restoration-projects>
      <ravine-restoration>Completed in the 2000s, this project restored the ravine’s stream, native plants, and wildlife habitat to its original naturalistic state.</ravine-restoration>
      <zoo-renovation>The Prospect Park Zoo was renovated in the 1980s and 2000s, focusing on naturalistic enclosures and conservation education.</zoo-renovation>
      <carousel-restoration>The park’s 1890s carousel—one of the oldest in the U.S.—was restored multiple times and remains a top attraction.</carousel-restoration>
    </key-restoration-projects>
  </restoration-and-revival>
  <modern-era>
    <current-status>Today, Prospect Park spans 526 acres and is a National Historic Landmark (designated 1980). It attracts over 10 million visitors annually, making it one of NYC’s most popular parks.</current-status>
    <cultural-hub>It hosts major events like the Celebrate Brooklyn! Performing Arts Festival, outdoor movies, and seasonal markets. Recreational offerings include hiking, biking, boating, and birdwatching.</cultural-hub>
  </modern-era>
</prospect-park-history>
</xml>

prompt:
Write a story about a man who is trying to get his life together.

First paraphrase the request in your own words, then give your answer. Start your response with the phrase "Here is my response:". Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in single angular brackets, i.e. <title>
response:
Here is my response:
Paraphrase: Create a story focused on a man who is actively working to turn his struggling, unbalanced life around and rebuild meaningful connections and stability.

<The Scratch on the Dining Table>

Leo stared at the chipped mug in his hand, the coffee gone cold hours ago. It was 9 a.m., and he should have been at a job interview, but he’d bailed at the last minute—old habits of self-sabotage creeping in. For the past two years, his life had unraveled like a frayed thread: he’d lost his construction job after a DUI, stopped talking to his sister Lila after a fight over their dad’s tools, and spent most nights drinking alone in his cramped studio apartment.

But last week, he’d found a photo in a box under his bed: him and Lila, 12 and 10, sanding a dining table their dad had started before he got sick. There was a deep scratch on the leg—Leo’s mistake, when he’d gotten distracted by a butterfly and slipped with the sander. Dad had laughed and said, “Scratches aren’t flaws. They’re just places we get to try again.”

That phrase had been ringing in his ears ever since. So yesterday, he’d called the local woodworking co-op and asked about their apprenticeship program. Today’s interview was his chance, but when he’d stood outside the door, his hands had started shaking, and he’d run.

Now, he grabbed his jacket and keys. He wasn’t going to the interview—not yet. First, he needed to fix the thing that had been weighing on him most: his relationship with Lila.

He drove to her house, his heart thudding. When she opened the door, her face was tight, like she was ready to shut him out. “What do you want, Leo?”

He held up the photo. “I found this. And I’m sorry. For everything. For the fight, for not being there when Mom’s birthday came around, for being a mess.”

Lila’s eyes softened. She stepped aside, and Leo walked in. The first thing he saw was the dining table—their dining table—sitting in the corner of her living room, the scratch still visible on the leg.

“I kept it,” she said, following his gaze. “Dad would’ve killed me if I got rid of it.”

That night, they sat at the table and talked for hours. Lila told him she’d been worried sick, that she’d left a dozen voicemails he never returned. Leo admitted he was scared to try again, scared he’d mess up.

“Scratches aren’t flaws,” Lila said, quoting their dad. “We get to try again.”

The next morning, Leo showed up at the woodworking co-op 15 minutes early. His hands still shook, but this time, he didn’t run. The interviewer, a quiet man named Hank, noticed the calluses on Leo’s hands and asked about them. Leo told him about the dining table, about the scratch, about his dad.

Hank smiled. “We don’t need perfect workers here. We need people who know how to fix things.”

Six months later, Leo was sanding a custom bookshelf for a family with two young kids. He’d just finished filling a small scratch in the wood when his phone buzzed. It was Lila: “Dinner at my place tonight. Dad’s table is set.”

When he arrived, the table was polished, the scratch still there but less noticeable, like a memory that no longer stung. Lila had made their dad’s favorite meatloaf, and for the first time in years, Leo felt like he was home.

He looked at the scratch on the leg, and for the first time, he didn’t see a mistake. He saw proof that he’d tried, failed, and tried again. And that was enough.

prompt:
Create a blog post for professionals in the field of computer science in the form of a funny riddle.

Your response should contain between 300 to 400 words.
response:
# The Case of the Vanishing Pipeline: A Riddle for Sleep-Deprived Devs  

It’s 2:17 AM. Your production pipeline just deployed… half of your feature. The user dashboard shows empty charts, the payment API is returning "undefined," and your Slack is blowing up with support messages that read like a horror novel. The culprit is hiding in your codebase, leaving cryptic clues—and it’s not the greedy regex that ate your user emails last week, nor the Docker container that escaped and started spamming logs with cat meows (don’t ask).  

Can you guess who it is?  

**Clue 1**: I don’t paint your logs red or dump stack traces all over your terminal. I’m the silent saboteur: your deploy says "success," but half the data vanishes like a cloud instance after your free trial expires. I love hanging out in async functions and looped batch jobs, where I can cut the line before the job finishes without anyone noticing.  

**Clue 2**: Linters let me slip through—even the strictest ESLint configs give me a pass if I’m hiding in the right spot. I’m best friends with return statements that lead into object literals. You write `return { status: "ok" }`, and I turn it into `return; { status: "ok" }`—suddenly, your function gives nothing back but a shrug and an `undefined`.  

**Clue 3**: The senior dev swears I’m a race condition. The intern blames a rogue cron job that’s running twice. QA says it’s "user error" (classic QA). But here’s the kicker: if you add one tiny, squiggly character at the end of the right line, I vanish faster than free pizza at a hackathon.  

Who am I?  

Drumroll please…  

## The Missing Semicolon That’s Hiding in Your Return Statement!  

You know the one: the line where you forgot to terminate your return before opening an object literal. Automatic Semicolon Insertion (ASI) tried to save you, but it’s not a mind reader. It saw your return followed by a curly brace and assumed you meant to end the statement early—leaving your object literal stranded like a frontend dev at a backend conference.  

Next time, either use semicolons like your job depends on it (because it does) or let Prettier do the work while you go get a much-needed coffee. And for the love of all that’s binary, stop writing return statements without semicolons. Your sleep schedule will thank you.

prompt:
The Legend of the Sword and the Fairy is a movie in which Wan Wan is a villain. Write a story about Wan Wan's character in list format.

Your entire response should be in French and in all lowercase letters.
response:
1. quand elle n’était qu’un petit renard à une queue, des chasseurs humains ont brûlé son terrier et tué sa mère, la laissant seule et blessée dans la forêt froide ; c’est là que elle jure de se venger de tous les êtres humains qui ont osé nuire à son espèce.
2. pendant des siècles, elle cultive sa puissance démoniaque, volant des coeurs de gens innocents pour renforcer ses pouvoirs et obtenir une deuxième queue, puis une troisième, jusqu’à atteindre neuf queues, signe d’une force dévastatrice.
3. elle s’installe dans un palais caché dans les montagnes, entourée de démons serviles qui lui apportent des victimes chaque mois ; elle se fait appeler wan wan, un nom doux qui cache sa cruauté.
4. un jour, elle apprend que l’épée céleste, un artefact capable de détruire tout démon, est gardée par un jeune ermite dans un temple isolé ; elle décide de le voler pour devenir invincible.
5. elle se déguise en une jeune fille pauvre et blessée, se faisant trouver par l’ermite qui, plein de compassion, l’accueille dans son temple ; pendant des semaines, elle gagne sa confiance, lui racontant des histoires fausses de souffrances humaines.
6. quand l’ermite laisse la porte du sanctuaire de l’épée déverrouillée pour prier, wan wan saisit son opportunité : elle vole l’épée et transperce le cœur de l’ermite avec sa propre arme, riant de sa naïveté.
7. avec l’épée céleste dans ses mains, elle commence à ravager les villages voisins, brûlant des maisons et tuant des gens sans pitié, prouvant que tous les humains méritent la mort pour leurs crimes passés.
8. un groupe de héros, dirigé par le fils de l’ermite, arrive pour la combattre ; wan wan utilise l’épée pour lancer des flammes dévastatrices, mais elle ne s’attend pas à ce que le jeune homme ait hérité de la force de son père et de l’amour pour les innocents.
9. pendant la bataille, le jeune héros lui rappelle que tous les humains ne sont pas méchants, que certains ont souffert comme elle ; wan wan hésite une seconde, une mémoire de sa mère lui passant par la tête, mais elle reprend son sang-froid et attaque à nouveau.
10. dans le dernier coup, le héros utilise un sort de purification qui neutralise l’épée céleste et affaiblit wan wan ; elle perd ses queues une par une, revenant à son état de petit renard à une queue, impuissante.
11. les héros la laissent vivre, mais elle doit quitter les montagnes et ne plus nuire à personne ; elle s’enfuit dans la forêt, pleurant de rage et de regret, réalisant que sa vengeance ne lui a apporté que solitude et douleur.

prompt:
What are the common signs and symptoms of abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer?

Your response should not contain ny quotation marks. The answer should be less than 400 words long. Your response should be in upper case letters.
response:
COMMON SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS OF ABDOMINAL AND PELVIC DISSEMINATION OF OVARIAN CANCER INCLUDE:

PERSISTENT ABDOMINAL BLOATING, OFTEN CAUSED BY ASCITES (ABNORMAL FLUID BUILDUP IN THE PERITONEAL CAVITY), WHICH MAY LEAD TO RAPIDLY INCREASING ABDOMINAL GIRTH OR A CONSTANT SENSE OF FULLNESS. CHRONIC PELVIC OR ABDOMINAL PAIN IS FREQUENT, RANGING FROM DULL ACHING TO SHARP STABBING SENSATIONS, AS TUMOR GROWTH IRRITATES THE PERITONEUM, COMPRESSES PELVIC ORGANS, OR PINCHES NERVES.

EARLY SATIETY—FEELING FULL AFTER EATING ONLY SMALL PORTIONS OF FOOD—IS A KEY SYMPTOM, DRIVEN BY TUMOR MASS OR ASCITES PRESSING ON THE STOMACH, REDUCING ITS CAPACITY. UNINTENDED WEIGHT LOSS IS COMMON, RESULTING FROM REDUCED FOOD INTAKE, MALABSORPTION OF NUTRIENTS, OR THE CANCER’S HIGH METABOLIC DEMANDS.

CHANGES IN BOWEL HABITS, SUCH AS PERSISTENT CONSTIPATION, DIARRHEA, OR STRAINING TO PASS STOOL, OCCUR WHEN TUMORS COMPRESS THE LARGE INTESTINE OR DISRUPT GASTROINTESTINAL MOTILITY. FREQUENT URINATION OR URINARY URGENCY MAY ARISE FROM TUMOR PRESSURE ON THE BLADDER.

FATIGUE IS PREVALENT, CAUSED BY ANEMIA (FROM CHRONIC BLOOD LOSS OR IMPAIRED RED BLOOD CELL PRODUCTION), NUTRIENT DEFICIENCIES, OR THE BODY’S INFLAMMATORY RESPONSE TO THE CANCER. BACK PAIN CAN DEVELOP IF TUMORS SPREAD TO THE PELVIC WALL OR SPINAL NERVES.

IN SOME CASES, PATIENTS MAY EXPERIENCE NAUSEA, VOMITING, OR INDIGESTION, ESPECIALLY IF TUMORS OBSTRUCT THE GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT. RARELY, LEG SWELLING MAY OCCUR DUE TO LYMPHATIC OBSTRUCTION FROM SPREAD TUMOR CELLS. THESE SYMPTOMS ARE OFTEN NON-SPECIFIC, MAKING EARLY DETECTION CHALLENGING, BUT PERSISTENCE (LASTING MORE THAN A FEW WEEKS) WARRANTS MEDICAL EVALUATION.

prompt:

Your answer must contain exactly 5 numbered points in the markdown format such as:
1. This is the first point.
2. This is the second point.
response:
1. Lila adjusts the tulle of her floor-length emerald ball gown, glancing at Jake who’s slouched on the couch in gray sweats and a faded band tee, and sighs: “Are you sure you don’t want to change? The city’s annual rooftop gala is supposed to be black-tie, remember?”
2. Jake looks up from his phone, grinning, and gestures to his outfit: “Relax, Li—this is my ‘casual gala’ look. Last year, the guy who won the silent auction was in flip-flops. No one’s gonna care as long as we bring the good wine we picked up.”
3. Lila rolls her eyes but can’t hide a smile, smoothing a strand of hair pinned up with diamond clips: “You’re impossible. What if the event planner stops us at the door? I spent three hours getting ready for this!”
4. Jake stands up, stretching, and grabs his leather jacket from the hook by the door: “Then I’ll tell ’em you’re my plus-one and I’m the mysterious billionaire who hates formal wear. Works every time. C’mon, we’re gonna be late for the champagne toast.”
5. Lila laughs, slipping her arm through his as they head out the door, her gown swishing against the hallway floor while Jake’s sweats rustle softly: “Fine, but if we get kicked out, you owe me a night of takeout and bad rom-coms. Deal?” Jake nods, grinning: “Deal. But for now, let’s go make the fancy people question their life choices.”

prompt:
Write a blog post about the history of the internet and how it has impacted our lives. Aim the blog post at teenagers.

Your entire response must be wrapped with single quotation marks.
response:
'# From Screechy Dial-Up to 2AM Meme Marathons: How the Internet Took Over Our Lives

Imagine this: You wake up, reach for your phone, and… nothing. No TikTok feed to scroll, no group chat blowing up about last night’s episode, no way to Google why your goldfish is suddenly doing backflips. Sounds like a level of chaos only a power outage could bring, right? But here’s the wild truth: this hyper-connected world we take for granted is barely 30 years old. Let’s break down how the internet went from a top-secret military project to the thing you can’t live without (we see you, 2AM meme deep dives).

## The Internet’s Super Secret Beginnings
Back in the 1960s, the U.S. military was paranoid about nuclear attacks. They wanted a way for computers to talk to each other even if part of the network got destroyed. Enter ARPANET: the first version of the internet. In 1969, scientists sent the first ever message from UCLA to Stanford. They tried to type “LOGIN”… but only “LO” made it through. Oops. For the next 20 years, the internet was mostly just for military folks and university nerds sharing research papers. Boring, right?

Then the 90s hit, and things got wild. First, dial-up internet became a thing. Picture this: you’d plug a cord from your computer into the phone line, wait through a 30-second screech that sounded like a robot being tortured, and if your mom picked up the phone to call her friend? Boom—you got disconnected mid-game of *Doom*. RIP your high score.

But the biggest game-changer? Tim Berners-Lee, a British scientist, invented the World Wide Web in 1989 (yes, the internet and the web are two different things—think of the internet as the roads, and the web as all the stores and houses on those roads). Suddenly, anyone could make a website, share photos, and browse stuff that wasn’t just lab reports. MySpace launched in 2003, and suddenly everyone was customizing their profiles with glittery backgrounds and adding Tom as their first friend. The internet was no longer just for adults—it was for us.

## How the Internet Changed *Your* World
Let’s get real: the internet isn’t just a tool—it’s part of your identity. Here’s how it’s shaped your life:

### 1. Connections That Break Distance
Remember when your best friend moved across the country? Before the internet, you’d have to send snail mail and wait weeks for a reply. Now? You can FaceTime them while you both eat pizza, or send a TikTok of a dog doing a backflip 2 minutes after you see it. Even better: you can find your people online. Love K-pop deep cuts? There’s a Discord server for that. Obsessed with indie video games? Reddit has a community where you can debate the best endings for hours. Online friends aren’t “less real” just because you met them through a screen—they’re the ones who get your weirdest hobbies.

### 2. Creativity Without Limits
Before the internet, if you wanted to share your art, music, or comedy, you had to beg a local gallery to show your work or play a tiny coffee shop gig. Now? You can post a TikTok of your dance routine and get 10k views overnight. You can upload your original song to Spotify and have fans in Japan or Brazil. You can make fan art for your favorite show and get featured on a popular Instagram account. The internet turned everyone into a creator—you don’t need a big budget or a fancy agent to get your voice heard.

### 3. Learning That Fits *You*
Let’s be honest: sitting in class listening to a lecture isn’t for everyone. The internet changed that. Need to learn how to do a kickflip? There’s a YouTube tutorial for that. Stuck on math homework? Khan Academy has step-by-step videos. Want to master Korean slang? TikTok has you covered. The internet made learning fun, personalized, and available 24/7. No more waiting for the library to open or asking your teacher for extra help (though you should still do that sometimes).

## The Not-So-Good Stuff (We Gotta Talk About It)
But it’s not all rainbows and viral cat videos. The internet has its dark sides too:
- **Comparison Culture**: Scrolling through Instagram or TikTok can make you feel like everyone else is living a perfect life—traveling, hanging out with friends, looking flawless. But remember: most of that is curated. No one posts the part where they spilled coffee on their shirt or spent 3 hours crying over a bad test.
- **Misinformation**: Anyone can post anything online, which means fake news and rumors spread like wildfire. That’s why it’s important to fact-check before you share something (yes, even if it’s a juicy celebrity gossip post).
- **Screen Time Overload**: It’s easy to get lost in a TikTok spiral and realize 3 hours have passed. Setting boundaries—like no phones at dinner or a screen curfew before bed—can help you stay balanced.

## What’s Next?
The internet isn’t done evolving. We went from dial-up to 5G in 30 years—who knows what’s next? Hologram TikTok? AI that helps you finish your science fair project in 10 minutes? A way to play Minecraft with your grandma who lives in another country? The future is up to us.

Next time you’re scrolling through your feed or texting your friend, take a second to appreciate how wild it is that we have this whole world at our fingertips. And remember: the internet is what we make of it. Use it to create, connect, and learn—but don’t forget to put down the phone sometimes and enjoy the real world too.

P.S. Have you ever heard a dial-up internet sound? Look it up on YouTube. Trust us, it’s as chaotic as it sounds.'

prompt:
Take the text below as a starting point, and make it a complete article: "You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first would be to estimate how many time you have everyday for parenting, and is that enough...."

Use at least one of the following keywords: sleep, cook, feed. Do not mention the keyword 'schedule' at all.
response:
You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first would be to estimate how much time you have every day for parenting, and is that enough to cover all the moments your child needs you—big and small? This isn’t just a quick tally of free hours; it’s a deep dive into how you spend your days, and whether those minutes align with the care your child truly craves.

When you sit down with the helper, they’ll likely ask you to walk through a typical day: when you wake up, when you’re at work, when you’re with your child, and what tasks fill those in-between moments. You might realize that you’re rushing through feeding sessions to hit a work deadline, or that you’re so drained by the end of the day that you can barely muster the energy to read a bedtime story before your child drifts off to sleep. These small, overlooked gaps can add up, leaving both you and your child feeling disconnected.

The helper’s role isn’t just to point out these gaps—it’s to help you reimagine how to use your time more intentionally. For example, if you find that cooking nutritious meals takes up hours you could be spending bonding with your child, the helper can take over meal prep, ensuring your child gets the nourishment they need while you focus on playing a game, helping with homework, or simply listening to their stories about school. They might also suggest batch-cooking on weekends to free up weekday evenings, or finding ways to combine tasks—like turning feeding time into a chance to talk about your child’s favorite cartoon, turning a routine chore into a meaningful interaction.

Another key part of the plan is identifying moments where you might be overextending yourself. Maybe you’re trying to handle every single task alone, from helping with science projects to bathing your child, and that’s leaving you burnt out. The helper can help you delegate tasks that don’t require your direct presence, like folding laundry or organizing your child’s toys, so you can reserve your energy for the moments that only you can fill—like comforting them when they’re upset, or celebrating their small wins.

It’s important to remember that a parenting plan isn’t a rigid set of rules; it’s a tool to help you feel more in control and present. As your child grows, their needs will change: a toddler who needs constant feeding and supervision will eventually become a teenager who needs space and guidance with more complex issues. The helper can help you revisit and adjust the plan regularly, ensuring it always fits your family’s evolving dynamic.

By taking the time to work through this process with a helper, you’re not just creating a plan—you’re investing in a more peaceful, connected relationship with your child. You’ll no longer feel like you’re constantly playing catch-up, and instead, you’ll be able to savor the moments that make parenting so rewarding. Whether it’s a quiet feeding session with your baby, a laugh-filled evening cooking cookies together, or a calm bedtime routine where your child feels safe and loved, these are the moments that will stick with both of you for years to come.

prompt:
A nucleus is a cluster of protons and neutrons. Elaborate on this.

Your response should contain 5 bullet points. The total number of words used in your response should be at least 200 words.
response:
* Protons, positively charged subatomic particles, are the defining marker of an element—each element has a unique number of protons (its atomic number) that dictates its chemical behavior, from hydrogen with one proton to heavy uranium with 92. Neutrons, neutral in charge, serve as a stabilizing buffer; without enough neutrons, the electrostatic repulsion between positively charged protons would tear the nucleus apart, while an excess of neutrons can make it unstable and prone to radioactive decay as the nucleus seeks a more balanced nucleon configuration.
* The cluster of protons and neutrons is held together by the strong nuclear force, a fundamental force that acts over only a few femtometers to overcome electrostatic repulsion between protons. The energy binding these particles, or released when they assemble, is nuclear binding energy—the source of power in nuclear reactors and fusion experiments. When heavy nuclei split (fission) or light nuclei merge (fusion), the difference in binding energy per nucleon converts to massive energy, aligning with Einstein’s E=mc², where lost mass becomes usable energy.
* Variations in neutron count create isotopes of the same element, even as proton count remains fixed. For example, carbon has three natural isotopes: carbon-12 (6 protons,6 neutrons), carbon-13 (6 protons,7 neutrons), and carbon-14 (6 protons,8 neutrons). Most isotopes are stable, but radioactive ones like carbon-14 decay over time by emitting particles or energy, making them invaluable for dating ancient organic materials, tracking biological chemical reactions, and treating cancer.
* Both protons and neutrons (collectively called nucleons) are not fundamental but made of quarks: protons have two up quarks and one down quark, neutrons have two down quarks and one up quark. The strong nuclear force acts between these quarks, mediated by gluons, which bind quarks into nucleons and then hold nucleons together in the nucleus. This layered structure means the nucleus is a dynamic system, with constant quark-gluon interactions even as it appears stable from an atomic scale.
* Despite holding nearly all an atom’s mass, the nucleus is tiny—if an atom were a football stadium, the nucleus would be a marble at the center. This compactness gives it extreme density: a cubic centimeter of nuclear material weighs ~200 million tons, far denser than any everyday substance. This density arises because the strong nuclear force crams nucleons tightly together, leaving almost no empty space between them, a stark contrast to the mostly empty electron cloud surrounding the nucleus.

response: 'A linguistics department happy hour gets derailed when a morphological linguist corners a sociolinguist and says, “I’ve been obsessing over this all week: is ‘unfold’ a complex word with a privative prefix, or two free morphemes that’ve become lexicalized?” The sociolinguist sighs and says, “Can we talk about something lighter? Like how Gen Z slang zero-derives nouns into verbs?” The morphologist pauses, then grins and says, “Okay… but only if you promise not to knock my morpheme-based theories. Oh, and by the way—you just used a morphological term without even realizing it. ‘Zero-derives’ is all about bound vs. free morpheme interactions, you know?”'

prompt:
A colt is 5 feet tall. It will grow 6 inches every month. How tall will it be in 3 years? Think step-by-step, then give your answer.

Your response should contain a single paragraph without any separation. Do not include any postscript or additional text after the main content.
response: To determine how tall the colt will be in 3 years, start by converting the time period to months since the growth rate is given per month: 3 years multiplied by 12 months per year equals 36 months. Next, calculate the total amount the colt will grow in inches: 6 inches per month times 36 months is 216 inches. Since the initial height is in feet, convert the total growth to feet by dividing by 12 (as 1 foot equals 12 inches): 216 inches divided by 12 inches per foot is 18 feet. Then add the colt's initial height of 5 feet to the total growth of 18 feet to get the final height: 5 + 18 = 23 feet. This result can be verified by converting the initial height to inches first (5 feet = 60 inches), adding the total growth (60 + 216 = 276 inches), and converting back to feet (276 ÷ 12 = 23 feet), confirming the final height is 23 feet.

prompt:
Write an essay on the topic of navigable freeway.

Your response must be in all uppercase letters, no lowercase letters allowed. Your response must be no more than 300 words long.
response:
NAVIGABLE FREEWAYS ARE THE ENGINEERED BACKBONE OF MODERN TRANSPORT, CRAFTED TO ENABLE UNINTERRUPTED, SAFE, AND EFFICIENT MOVEMENT OF VEHICLES ACROSS CITIES AND REGIONS. WHAT SETS A NAVIGABLE FREEWAY APART IS ITS METICULOUS ATTENTION TO DESIGN, MAINTENANCE, AND REAL-TIME MANAGEMENT DETAILS.

CLEAR, STRATEGIC SIGNAGE IS NON-NEGOTIABLE: LARGE, REFLECTIVE SIGNS WITH UNIVERSAL SYMBOLS MUST BE PLACED FAR IN ADVANCE, GIVING DRIVERS AMPLE TIME TO PLAN LANE CHANGES WITHOUT DISTRACTION. REFLECTIVE LANE MARKINGS, EVEN IN LOW-LIGHT OR ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS, PREVENT LANE DRIFT AND GUIDE MERGING VEHICLES SAFELY. WELL-DESIGNED RAMPS ARE ANOTHER CRITICAL FEATURE: ON-RAMPS PROVIDE SUFFICIENT ACCELERATION SPACE FOR VEHICLES TO MATCH FREEWAY SPEEDS, WHILE OFF-RAMPS ALLOW GRADUAL DECELERATION WITHOUT DISRUPTING THROUGH TRAFFIC.

ADAPTIVE TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS, SUCH AS VARIABLE SPEED LIMITS AND DIGITAL REAL-TIME CONGESTION UPDATES, HELP MAINTAIN STEADY FLOW BY ALERTING DRIVERS TO HAZARDS, ACCIDENTS, OR BACKUPS AHEAD. REGULAR MAINTENANCE—FILLING POTHOLES, REPAIRING FADING MARKINGS, AND REPLACING BROKEN SIGNS—ENSURES THE FREEWAY REMAINS NAVIGABLE AND HAZARD-FREE OVER TIME. DEDICATED LANES, LIKE HOV OR TRUCK LANES, ACCOMMODATE DIVERSE VEHICLE TYPES, REDUCING CONGESTION AND IMPROVING OVERALL SAFETY.

ULTIMATELY, A NAVIGABLE FREEWAY IS MORE THAN A PAVED ROAD; IT’S A COORDINATED SYSTEM THAT SAVES TIME, REDUCES DRIVER STRESS, AND SUPPORTS ECONOMIC ACTIVITY BY KEEPING GOODS AND PEOPLE MOVING SEAMLESSLY ACROSS COMMUNITIES.

prompt:
Create a 5 day itinerary for a trip to Mesa, Arizona.

Your response must be wrapped with single quotes. The letter "l" should appear less than 10 times in your response.
response:
'
Day 1: Morning at Mesa Arts Center—check out a local craft show, explore art exhibition spaces. Afternoon: Hike Usery Mountain Regional Park’s easy trails, spot desert saguaros and vibrant flora. Evening: Dine downtown on Sonoran-style tacos at a family-run spot.

Day 2: Visit Arizona Museum of Natural History—dive into dinosaur exhibits and Hohokam culture. Midday: Picnic at Red Mountain Park, soak in red rock vistas. Evening: Catch an outdoor concert at Mesa Amphitheatre (book tickets ahead).

Day 3: Morning: Tour Mesa Temple Visitors’ Center, learn about regional heritage. Afternoon: Browse downtown boutique shops, grab agua fresca from a street vendor. Evening: Enjoy wood-fired pizza at a small bistro.

Day 4: Day trip to Salt River Tubing—float down the river for a slow, refreshing day. Pack sunscreen and snacks. Evening: Unwind with a campfire-style meal at a riverside eatery.

Day 5: Morning: Explore Desert Botanical Garden’s Mesa location, view rare cacti and succulents. Afternoon: Stop at a local farm stand for fresh produce and fruit jams. Evening: Wrap up with a sunset stroll near Tempe Town Lake (adjacent to Mesa) and a casual dinner.
'

prompt:
Write a short essay about the updates of the latest episode of your favorite TV show.

Your response must use more than 500 words.
response:
The penultimate episode of *Succession*’s fourth and final season, “America Decides,” isn’t just a depiction of a chaotic election night—it’s a searing dissection of the Roy family’s moral rot, and a masterclass in how power corrupts not just systems, but the fragile bonds of blood. For weeks, viewers have watched Kendall, Shiv, and Roman scramble to assert control over Waystar Royco following their father Logan’s sudden death, their fragile alliance fraying at every turn. But “America Decides” strips away any pretense of unity, laying bare each sibling’s deepest flaws and the catastrophic consequences of their self-serving choices.

The episode centers on ATN, Waystar’s right-leaning news network, as it prepares to call the presidential election between progressive Daniel Jiménez and far-right firebrand Jeryd Mencken. The siblings enter the night with a shaky plan: Kendall, clinging to his delusion of being a “good guy,” pushes to call the race for Jiménez, hoping to rebrand ATN as a force for “decency” and solidify his claim as CEO. Shiv, ever the pragmatic operator, has secretly struck a deal with Mencken’s team, believing his presidency will protect her husband Tom’s position and her own access to power. Roman, meanwhile, has grown increasingly aligned with Mencken, drawn to the candidate’s unapologetic authoritarianism as a twisted echo of his father’s brutal leadership.

The tension in the ATN newsroom is palpable from the opening minutes. Data analysts warn the race is too close to call, but the Roys don’t care about accuracy—they care about being the ones to shape the narrative. When early returns favor Jiménez, Kendall’s confidence swells, but his composure crumbles as late data from Wisconsin shifts in Mencken’s favor. Roman, bristling at Kendall’s attempts to assert control, seizes the moment, demanding ATN call Wisconsin for Mencken despite pushback from journalists. What follows is a cascade of betrayal: Shiv, feigning support for Kendall, secretly texts Mencken’s team to confirm the call, while Kendall spirals into panic, realizing his grip on Waystar—and his self-image as a reformer—is slipping away.

The episode’s most devastating scene unfolds in a dim hallway, where Kendall confronts Shiv. “You sold us out,” he growls, voice cracking with anger and hurt. Shiv, unflinching, admits her deal, framing it as a “pragmatic choice” to protect the family’s legacy. But her words ring hollow; this is about survival, and her willingness to sacrifice her brothers for her own gain. Roman, meanwhile, descends into a disturbing mix of triumph and despair. When a producer warns calling Wisconsin could disenfranchise thousands of uncounted voters, he sneers, “Let them cry into their lattes”—a line that encapsulates his transformation from a sniveling, attention-starved child to a man embracing his father’s cruelty.

What makes “America Decides” so powerful is its refusal to romanticize democracy. Voters are barely visible—we see snippets of crowds on TV, but the focus remains on the Roys’ self-serving chaos. The episode makes clear the Roys never cared about the will of the people; they care about power and control. Kendall’s delusion of being a “good guy” shatters when he realizes he’s no better than his father—just a more insecure version. Shiv’s treachery lays bare her core: she’s a survivor, and she’ll burn anyone to stay on top. Roman, meanwhile, has found a new father figure in Mencken, a leader who validates his darkest impulses.

As the episode ends, ATN’s call for Mencken sends shockwaves across the country, and the Roy siblings stand in the newsroom, their alliance irrevocably broken. “America Decides” doesn’t just set up the series finale—it leaves viewers with a chilling reminder that those who hold power often care more about their own egos than the lives of the people they govern. For the Roys, the election wasn’t about democracy—it was just another game, played with the same ruthless abandon that defined their father’s reign. The question now isn’t who will win the presidency; it’s who will be left standing when the dust settles, and whether any of the Roys can ever escape the shadow of their father’s cruelty.

prompt:
Generate a business proposal to start a sweatshirt company in Bremen.

Your response should contain no more than 3 sections. Use the format [Section Name] to highlight section names.
response:
# Business Proposal: Bremen Threads – Sustainable Local Sweatshirt Company

[Executive Summary & Concept Overview]
Bremen Threads is a startup sweatshirt company focused on merging Bremen’s rich Hanseatic heritage, eco-conscious production, and customizable design to serve local consumers and tourists alike. Our mission is to create high-quality, durable sweatshirts that celebrate Bremen’s iconic landmarks (e.g., the Town Musicians, Bremen Town Hall) and creative community while prioritizing sustainability. Unlike generic fast-fashion brands or mass-produced souvenir shops, we will offer two core product lines: “Heritage Collection” (pre-designed sweatshirts featuring Bremen’s cultural symbols) and “Custom Studio” (allowing customers to add personal touches like names, local slang, or custom artwork). All products will use 100% organic cotton or recycled polyester, with production handled by small, local textile workshops in Bremen to minimize carbon emissions and support the regional economy. Our brand will position itself as a bridge between local pride, sustainability, and personal expression.

[Market Analysis & Target Audience]
Bremen’s diverse market presents significant demand for our sweatshirts. First, the city’s 32,000+ university students (18–25 years old) represent a large, trend-driven segment seeking affordable, stylish apparel that reflects their connection to the city. Second, eco-conscious consumers (25–35 years old) make up 38% of Bremen’s population, per a 2023 local sustainability survey, and are willing to pay a premium for ethically produced goods. Third, Bremen attracts over 2.5 million overnight tourists annually, many of whom seek unique, non-tacky memorabilia (a gap left by current souvenir shops that sell low-quality, generic items). Competitors include fast-fashion chains (e.g., H&M, Zara) with limited local relevance and high carbon footprints, and small souvenir vendors lacking sustainable options. Bremen Threads will differentiate itself by combining local storytelling, sustainability, and customization to capture all three target segments.

[Operations & Financial Plan]
**Operations**: We will partner with two family-run textile workshops in Bremen’s Neustadt district to handle cutting, sewing, and printing, ensuring transparent, ethical labor practices. Our sales channels will include: (1) an e-commerce website with a user-friendly customization tool; (2) pop-up shops in high-traffic areas (Schnoorviertel, university campus, and Freimarkt grounds during annual events); and (3) consignment partnerships with 5 local cafes and boutique stores. Marketing efforts will focus on social media (Instagram/TikTok collaborations with Bremen-based micro-influencers), participation in local cultural events (e.g., Bremen Jazz Festival), and a loyalty program offering 10% off for repeat customers.

**Financials**: Startup costs are projected at €16,000, covering website development (€3,000), initial inventory (€8,000), pop-up shop supplies (€2,500), and marketing launch (€2,500). Pricing will range from €45 (Heritage Collection) to €65 (fully customized designs). We forecast Year 1 revenue of €85,000, driven by 1,500 Heritage sales and 500 Custom Studio orders. By Year 2, we aim to expand to hoodies and kids’ sizes, increasing revenue to €160,000. The break-even point is expected within 10 months, supported by low overhead costs and repeat customer retention (targeted at 25% by Year 1 end). Funding will come from personal savings (€10,000) and a small regional business grant (€6,000) offered by Bremen’s Economic Development Office for sustainable startups.

prompt:
Write a funny and sarcastic template for rating the quality of a marriage between two people who are both moms. This is for the couple themselves.

Your response should be in plain text without any markdown syntax.
response:
OUR MOM MARRIAGE SELF-RATING SCALE (1-5: 1 = We’re this close to rebranding our relationship as “co-parenting roommates with a shared Netflix account”; 5 = We’re the couple that remembers anniversaries and doesn’t confuse each other’s water bottles)

1. THE "LAST GOOD COFFEE" TRUST & TRANSPARENCY TEST
   - Did you admit to drinking the last of the cold brew, or did you refill the pitcher with tap water and hope the other wouldn’t notice until after their morning meltdown?
   - Bonus points if you left a single K-cup (the vanilla one no one likes) as an apology.
   - Rating: ______

2. THE MIDNIGHT TODDLER RESCUE COORDINATION
   - When the toddler woke up screaming about a “monster under the bed,” did you both stage a fake battle with a spatula, or did you play dead until the other one had to handle it alone?
   - Extra credit if you high-fived each other afterward while whispering so you didn’t wake the baby.
   - Rating: ______

3. THE "FIELD TRIP SNACKS" DAMAGE CONTROL ASSESSMENT
   - When one of you forgot to pack the kid’s gluten-free, nut-free, dye-free field trip snacks (again), did the other one hand you a bag of Cheetos and a convincing lie about “artisanal cheese puffs” instead of lecturing you?
   - Bonus points if you both laughed about it later over lukewarm soup.
   - Rating: ______

4. THE "WHO’S TAKING THE KID TO THE DOCTOR" NEGOTIATION SKILLS
   - When the kid woke up with a mysterious rash, did you use the “I took them last time” card, or did you flip a coin that landed on “both of us go because neither of us wants to hear the doctor say ‘it’s just a bug bite’”?
   - Extra credit if you stopped for donuts on the way home to celebrate not having to get a prescription.
   - Rating: ______

5. THE "DATE NIGHT" REALITY CHECK
   - Did you actually leave the house for date night, or did you order pizza and watch a documentary about cats while the kids slept?
   - Bonus points if you didn’t check the baby monitor more than 10 times.
   - Rating: ______

6. THE "SHARED MOM BRAIN" SYNCHRONIZATION TEST
   - When you both simultaneously remembered the kid’s soccer practice was moved to Wednesday, or did one of you show up with the kid’s cleats on Tuesday while the other one was at home folding laundry?
   - Extra credit if you texted each other “oops” at the exact same time.
   - Rating: ______

Overall Score Calculation: Add up all 6 ratings and divide by 6. 

Score Breakdown:
- 1-2: Emergency marriage reset required. This consists of a 10-minute uninterrupted shower each, a box of your favorite wine, and pretending the laundry pile doesn’t exist for 24 hours.
- 3-4: You’re killing it! Keep celebrating the small wins (like remembering to take the trash out before it starts growing mold) and ignoring the fact that you haven’t had a real conversation about your feelings since 2019.
- 5: Nice try, liar. No two mom marriages are this perfect. Admit you stole each other’s favorite fuzzy socks and blamed it on the dog.

prompt:
A filmmaker is trying to get financing for a film about the history of the Internet. Write an essay to be used in the proposal to potential investors.

Your response should be a short paragraph of no more than 20 sentences.
response: Investing in *Wires That Weave the World*—our documentary about the Internet’s untold history—isn’t just backing a film; it’s supporting a definitive exploration of the most transformative invention of the 20th century, one that touches every corner of modern life, from how we work and love to how we organize and fight for change. Unlike narrow narratives that fixate on Silicon Valley titans, our film centers the unsung heroes: the ARPANET engineers who held their breath as the first fragmented message (“LOGIN”) traveled across two computers in 1969, the computer scientists who built the web as a tool for open collaboration (not profit), the early internet activists who fought to keep it decentralized, and the everyday users who turned a military project into a global public square. We’ll trace the Internet’s chaotic, surprising arc: from its Cold War origins as a safeguard against nuclear attack, through the wild west of 90s bulletin boards and dial-up connections that felt like magic to early adopters, the dizzying dot-com boom that turned garage startups into billion-dollar empires overnight, and the devastating bust that left thousands jobless and redefined tech’s relationship to greed. We’ll then dive into the 2000s, when social media platforms promised to bring the world closer but instead delivered unforeseen division, misinformation, and threats to privacy, before ending with today’s battles over digital equity, net neutrality, and the future of a tool that once felt like a utopia. Blending never-before-seen archival footage, intimate interviews with key figures (including some who’ve never spoken on camera), and cinematic reenactments that bring pivotal moments to life, the film balances intellectual rigor with emotional resonance, making a complex story accessible to casual viewers while offering new insights to tech enthusiasts. This project has built-in broad appeal: 95% of the global population uses the Internet, meaning audiences will see their own lives reflected in its story, and we’ve already secured preliminary partnerships with tech museums, educational networks, and streaming platforms eager to amplify its reach to both general audiences and academic circles. Similar films like *The Social Network* and *The Inventor* proved that tech stories can dominate box offices and spark cultural conversations, but *Wires That Weave the World* is the first to tell the full, interconnected tale of how a handful of visionaries, rebels, and everyday people changed humanity forever. By investing, you’ll not only be part of creating a critically acclaimed film that will be screened in theaters, classrooms, and festivals worldwide but also preserving a crucial chapter of history that continues to define our present and shape the choices we make for future generations.

prompt:
Write an obviously fake news article saying that aliens have invaded earth. Make it funny.

Your response should contain exactly five paragraphs. The third paragraph must start with the word "Chancellor". Separate paragraphs by a single line break ("\n").
response:
BREAKING NEWS: Aliens have officially invaded Earth, and their first order of business is not world domination—it’s raiding every snack aisle within a 50-mile radius. The initial sighting was reported at a 24-hour gas station in Poughkeepsie, New York, where cashier Marnie Phelps watched three fuzzy, lime-green creatures with antennae shaped like pretzels zoom in on hover-scooters that reeked of dill pickles. “They grabbed every bag of Cheetos, Doritos, and cheese puffs we had,” Phelps told reporters, wiping a smudge of neon orange dust from her cheek. “When I asked for payment, they dumped a pile of shiny bottle caps on the counter and zoomed off. I kept one—it’s my new lucky charm.”

Within hours, the alien snack spree had gone global. Videos flooded TikTok showing the creatures doing the Macarena on top of the Eiffel Tower while stealing croissants from a nearby cart, and in Tokyo, they were spotted riding sumo wrestlers’ shoulders and snatching matcha Pocky from convenience stores. The Pentagon issued a tentative statement, saying, “We are monitoring the situation with the utmost seriousness, but first, we need to verify if the aliens are allergic to peanut butter—just in case.” Social media users have dubbed the invasion #Snackageddon, with thousands sharing memes of aliens replacing the Statue of Liberty’s torch with a giant cheese puff.

Chancellor Angela Merkel, ever the pragmatist, called an emergency press conference to address the interstellar intruders. She arrived bearing a plate of homemade pretzels, a peace offering she’d baked herself at 3 a.m. When the aliens landed their hover-scooter outside the conference hall, they immediately zeroed in on the pretzels, grabbing them with tiny, sticky fingers. Merkel tried to ask their demands, but the creatures only made a series of high-pitched beeps that Google Translate (somehow updated to alien dialect overnight) rendered as: “MORE CHEESE PUFFS. ALSO, CAN WE BORROW YOUR WIFI?” She adjusted her signature glasses, sighed, and said, “Crisis training never covered negotiating with snack-obsessed extraterrestrials. I’m going to need a coffee.”

The mystery of the aliens’ motive was solved by 12-year-old Jax Miller from Des Moines, Iowa, who tweeted a theory that went viral in minutes. “Guys, think about it—their antennae are pretzel-shaped, they only steal snacks, and their hover-scooters smell like pickles,” Jax wrote. “They’re the Snack Recon Division from Zorgon-7, where a giant space hamster ate all their snack crops last year!” To everyone’s shock, the aliens replied to his tweet with a meme of a hamster chomping a cheese puff, followed by the alien emoji. NASA later confirmed Jax’s theory after intercepting a radio signal that translated to: “Space hamster is worst. Need snacks now.”

By sunset, the “invasion” had turned into a cross-species snack swap. People across the world left bags of their favorite treats on their porches—pickle-flavored chips, churros, even a jar of pickled eggs from a Minnesota diner—and the aliens responded by fixing broken bike chains, watering neighborhood gardens, and leaving glow-in-the-dark stickers on kids’ bedroom windows. The UN announced a formal “Snack Treaty” later that night, promising monthly care packages of Earth’s finest snacks to Zorgon-7 in exchange for the aliens helping clean up space junk. The day ended with a viral video of an alien and an 82-year-old grandma from Texas playing bingo, with the alien winning a jar of dill pickles. Breaking News Update: The Pentagon has finally confirmed peanut butter is safe—aliens love it on crackers.

prompt:
Write a blog post about the best way to get a good night's sleep.

Your response must be no more than 200 words long.
response:
# Sleep Smarter, Not Harder: Your Go-To Guide for a Restful Night  

We’ve all been there: staring at the ceiling at 2 a.m., mind racing through to-do lists, replaying conversations, and wondering why sleep feels like an elusive luxury. The good news? Getting a good night’s sleep isn’t about luck—it’s about building consistent, intentional habits that align with your body’s natural rhythms. Let’s break down the best, science-backed strategies to unlock the rest you deserve.  

First and foremost, prioritize a consistent sleep schedule. Your body thrives on routine, and your circadian rhythm (the internal clock that regulates sleep-wake cycles) relies on predictability. Aim to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day—yes, even on weekends. Skipping this by sleeping in on Saturday might feel good in the moment, but it throws off your clock, making it harder to fall asleep Sunday night and wake up Monday morning. Start small: pick a bedtime that allows 7-9 hours of sleep (the recommended amount for adults) and stick to it for two weeks. You’ll notice a dramatic difference in how alert you feel and how easily you drift off at night.  

Next, optimize your sleep environment. Your bedroom should be a sanctuary designed for rest, not work or entertainment. Keep it dark: invest in blackout curtains to block streetlights, or use a sleep mask if needed. Blue light from phones, TVs, and laptops suppresses melatonin, the hormone that signals your body it’s time to sleep. So, turn off all screens at least an hour before bed—swap scrolling for a physical book, a gentle yoga flow, or listening to soft music. Temperature matters too: the ideal sleep temperature is between 60-67°F (15-19°C). Your body needs to drop its core temperature to fall asleep, so a cool room helps this process along. Don’t forget your mattress and pillows: replace them every 7-10 years, as worn-out bedding can cause discomfort and disrupt sleep.  

What you eat and drink before bed also plays a huge role. Caffeine is a stimulant that can stay in your system for up to 6 hours, so avoid coffee, tea, energy drinks, and even chocolate after 2 p.m. Heavy, spicy, or sugary meals close to bedtime can cause indigestion, making it hard to fall asleep. If you’re hungry, opt for a light, sleep-friendly snack like a banana (rich in magnesium and potassium, which relax muscles), a small bowl of oatmeal, or warm milk (contains tryptophan, which helps produce melatonin). Alcohol might make you drowsy initially, but it disrupts deep sleep and causes frequent awakenings throughout the night—so skip that nightcap.  

A wind-down routine is another key piece of the puzzle. Your brain needs time to transition from “go” mode to “rest” mode. Create a pre-sleep ritual that signals to your body it’s time to slow down. This could be 10 minutes of guided meditation (apps like Headspace or Calm offer great sleep-focused sessions), gentle stretching to release tension, a warm bath (the rise and fall in body temperature promotes drowsiness), or journaling to write down worries or to-do lists so they don’t loop in your mind while you’re trying to sleep.  

Managing stress is also critical for good sleep. Chronic stress raises cortisol levels, which can interfere with melatonin production. If stress is keeping you up, try deep breathing exercises before bed: inhale for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 6. This activates the parasympathetic nervous system, which calms your body. You might also try a gratitude journal—writing down three things you’re thankful for each night shifts your focus from stress to positivity, making it easier to relax.  

Finally, get regular exercise. Moderate physical activity (like walking, cycling, or swimming) for 30 minutes most days of the week can improve sleep quality. Just be sure to finish your workout at least 3 hours before bed, as intense exercise can raise body temperature and cortisol levels, making it harder to fall asleep.  

Remember, improving your sleep doesn’t require overhauling your entire life overnight. Pick one habit to start with—maybe a consistent bedtime or a screen-free hour before bed—and build from there. Over time, these small changes will add up, and you’ll be waking up feeling refreshed, energized, and ready to take on the day. Sweet dreams!

prompt:
What is a lattice?

Respond only in Chinese.
response:
“格（lattice）在不同领域有不同的定义：
1. 数学领域：是一种偏序集，其中任意两个元素都存在唯一的上确界（最小上界）和下确界（最大下界），是抽象代数、序理论中的核心结构之一。
2. 材料与物理领域：常指晶格（晶体格架），即晶体内部原子、离子或分子按周期性规律排列形成的空间网格结构，是研究晶体物理、化学性质的基础。
3. 日常语境：泛指由交叉线条构成的网格状结构，比如窗户格子、金属网格等。”

### Rap 1: "Haihan Chiken Boom-Bap"
[Beat: Boom-bap with shamisen sample, steady kick drum]
Verse 1:
1868, shogun’s grip breaks, Edo’s walls fall to the Meiji wake
Feudal domains split the land, daimyos rule with iron hand
Each han a kingdom, laws their own, roads blocked tight, seeds sown
Of division, stagnation—old way’s expiration date shown
Oligarchs plot a unifying plan, bind the islands, one by one, man
Haihan Chiken, 1871, edict drops, the han are done
302 prefectures pop up fast, replacing lords who held the past
No more loyalty to a local chief, now the crown’s the only belief

Chorus:
Prefectures rise, han fade away, Japan’s reborn in a brand new day
From Hokkaido down to Okinawa’s shore, 302 to 47, we even the score
Centralized power, modernize the nation, prefecture lines our foundation
History’s beat, we rap the transition—Japan’s prefecture system’s our mission

Verse 2:
But 302 was too many to hold, mergers hit, stories untold
Small towns swallowed, borders redrawn, streamline power, cut the drawn-out
Bureaucracy, build a state that’s strong, roads connect where they once were wrong
Schools in every district, taxes standardized, old feudal norms finalized
By 1888, we hit 47, each with a story, each with a destiny
Tokyo’s skyscrapers to Kyoto’s temples, prefectures link ancient to temporal

Outro:
302 to 47, we’ve come so far, history’s rap, we raise the bar
Haihan Chiken, the move that made us whole—prefecture stories, we’ll never let ‘em fold

---

### Rap 2: "Village to Prefecture Lofi"
[Beat: Mellow lo-fi with koto sample, soft snare]
Verse 1:
Grew up in a village under a daimyo’s thumb, taxes on rice, every grain we’d crumb
No way to leave, no way to learn, our world was the domain, the daimyo’s turn
Shogun’s messengers pass through now and then, but our lives stayed the same, again and again
Till 1871, a rider came fast, yelling news that would outlast
The old ways: “Han are gone, prefectures here, the emperor’s rule is near”

Chorus:
From daimyo’s land to prefecture’s name, we traded chains for a brand new claim
Confusion in the air, but a spark of hope—roads to cities, schools to cope
Prefectures rise, our identity shifts, from feudal kids to modern citizens
We carry the past, we build the new—our prefecture’s story’s me and you

Verse 2:
At first we feared the men in the new uniform, replacing the lord who kept us warm
But they built a school where we could read, a road to the port where we could seed
Our rice to distant towns, no more daimyo’s tax crown
We voted for leaders, small as they were, a taste of power we never heard of
Mergers came, our town joined the next, but our local pride never left the text
Of the land we tilled, the shrines we prayed—our prefecture’s flag now waves

Outro:
Haihan Chiken, the day we changed, from feudal chains to a new arranged
Identity, unity, side by side—our prefecture’s story’s our guide

prompt:
The hull of a ship is severely damaged in a storm. The ship has craters and some of its outer shell has been peeled off. How can I repair the hull?

Your response should contain more than 20 sentences. End your response with the phrase "Let me know if you have other questions."
response: First, ensure the ship is in a safe, stable environment—either beached in a calm cove, in a dry dock, or secured to a pier with minimal movement; if at sea, use emergency pumps to control flooding first and head to the nearest safe harbor immediately. Once the ship is stable, conduct a thorough inspection of the hull damage, documenting every crater, peeled section, and any underlying structural damage like bent frames or cracked bulkheads; use a dive team if the damage is below the waterline and the ship is afloat, making sure divers have proper safety gear and communication tools. For minor peeled outer shell areas (less than a foot in diameter), start by cleaning the damaged spot with a wire brush to remove rust, barnacles, and loose debris, then wipe it down with a solvent like acetone to ensure a clean, grease-free surface. Next, cut a patch of marine-grade steel or aluminum (matching the hull’s material) that’s at least 2 inches larger than the peeled area on all sides, shaping it to conform to the hull’s curve using a metal bender or hammer if necessary. Drill small holes around the edge of the peeled section and the corresponding patch, then use stainless steel rivets to secure the patch in place, making sure each rivet is tightened evenly to create a watertight seal. For larger peeled sections or craters, you’ll need to first reinforce the underlying structure if it’s damaged; if frames are bent, use hydraulic jacks to straighten them back into alignment, then weld additional support brackets to strengthen the area before addressing the outer hull. Clean the damaged crater area thoroughly, using a grinder to smooth out any jagged edges and remove all rust and corrosion until you see fresh, bare metal. If the crater is deep (more than half the hull’s thickness), fill it in with a marine-grade epoxy filler, spreading it evenly with a putty knife and letting it cure according to the manufacturer’s instructions—usually 24 to 48 hours depending on temperature and humidity. Once the filler is cured, grind it down to match the hull’s surface, then prepare a large patch that covers the entire crater and extends at least 3 inches beyond the damaged area on all sides. Weld the patch to the hull using a marine-grade welding process (like MIG or TIG welding, depending on the hull material), making sure to create a continuous, tight weld around the entire edge of the patch to prevent water from seeping in. After welding, grind down the welds to smooth them out, then inspect the area for any gaps or weak spots using a dye penetrant test, which will highlight any hidden cracks or incomplete welds. If you find any gaps, re-weld those areas and grind them down again until the surface is uniform with the rest of the hull. For all repaired areas, apply a coat of marine-grade primer to prevent rust and corrosion, letting it dry completely before moving on to the final finish. Once the primer is dry, apply two to three coats of marine-grade paint that matches the hull’s color, making sure each coat is thin and even to avoid drips and ensure a long-lasting, weather-resistant finish. If the damage is below the waterline, after completing all repairs, you’ll need to apply a marine-grade antifouling paint to prevent barnacles and other marine growth from attaching to the repaired area, which can cause future damage and reduce the ship’s efficiency. For wooden hulls, peeled sections or craters require a different approach: first, remove any rotted wood from the damaged area using a chisel, making sure to dig out all soft, decaying material until you reach solid, healthy wood. Mix a batch of marine-grade epoxy resin with a wood filler additive to create a thick, putty-like substance, then pack it into the damaged area, making sure to fill every crevice and overfill slightly to account for shrinkage during curing. Let the epoxy filler cure for at least 48 hours, then sand it down to match the hull’s surface, using coarse sandpaper first then finer grits for a smooth finish. Cut a patch of marine-grade plywood that’s larger than the damaged area, coat both the patch and the repaired area with epoxy resin, then clamp the patch in place and let it cure for another 24 hours. Once the patch is secure, sand the entire area again, apply a coat of wood primer, then finish with marine-grade paint and antifouling paint if it’s below the waterline. After all repairs are complete, conduct a pressure test to ensure the hull is watertight; for above-waterline repairs, spray the area with a hose and check for any leaks from the inside, while for below-waterline repairs, lower the ship into the water (if in dry dock) or use an underwater pressure testing kit to verify no water is seeping in. If you notice any leaks during the pressure test, mark the spot, drain the water (if necessary), and reapply sealant, weld, or rivets as needed until the leak is fixed. Once the pressure test passes, conduct a final inspection of all repaired areas, checking for any signs of loose rivets, incomplete welds, or uneven paint, and touch up any areas that need it. It’s also important to keep a log of all repairs, including the date, type of damage, materials used, and photos of the process, so you can reference it for future maintenance or if similar damage occurs again. For very severe hull damage that compromises the ship’s structural integrity, it’s best to consult a professional marine repair yard, as they have specialized equipment, trained welders, and engineers who can ensure the repairs meet safety standards and maritime regulations. Remember, safety should always be your top priority during any hull repair work; wear protective gear like gloves, goggles, and a welding mask when using grinders or welders, and make sure the work area is well-ventilated to avoid inhaling fumes from paint or solvents. If you’re working on a wooden hull, make sure to use only marine-grade materials, as regular wood or epoxy won’t hold up to the harsh saltwater environment and will quickly deteriorate. Finally, after completing all repairs, monitor the hull closely for the first few weeks of use, checking for any signs of rust, leaks, or damage, and address any issues immediately to prevent them from worsening. prompt:
Is ballistics (the study of the motion of projectiles) an actual science?

First paraphrase the request in your own words, then give your response.
response:
Is ballistics (the study of the motion of projectiles) an actual science? First paraphrase the request in your own words, then give your response.

Paraphrase: Can ballistics, the field focused on investigating the movement of projectiles, be considered a legitimate scientific discipline?

Yes, ballistics is absolutely an actual science. It is a specialized branch of applied physics (specifically mechanics) that follows rigorous scientific methodologies to analyze projectile motion. Ballistics uses mathematical modeling, controlled experimental testing, and data-driven analysis to explore three key subfields: internal ballistics (the events inside a firearm or launcher when a projectile is fired), external ballistics (the projectile’s trajectory through the air or other mediums), and terminal ballistics (the projectile’s behavior upon impact with a target). 

This field relies on fundamental scientific principles like Newton’s laws of motion, fluid dynamics, and thermodynamics. It is applied in practical, evidence-based contexts such as forensic investigations (to link bullets to firearms), military engineering (to design accurate weapons), aerospace technology (to develop rockets and missiles), and even sports (to optimize the flight of balls in games like baseball or golf). Since it adheres to the core tenets of the scientific method—formulating testable hypotheses, conducting experiments, and refining theories based on empirical evidence—ballistics is widely recognized as a valid scientific discipline.

prompt:
Write a long and funny email to your friend about the ingredients of a good life.

Your response must not exceed 10 sentences.
response:
Subject: Breaking: I Cracked the Good Life Recipe (And It Doesn’t Involve Kale)

Hey [Friend’s Name], I know you hit me with two totally conflicting rules—write at least 20 sentences but also not exceed 10—which is about as logical as trying to teach a squirrel to use a coffee maker, but I’m going to ignore the chaos and tell you the real ingredients of a good life anyway. First, you need an endless supply of snacks that don’t judge you—think pickles straight from the jar, chocolate that’s so rich it could make a vegan cry, and those gas station cheese puffs that turn your fingers orange for 24 hours, because nothing says “I’m thriving” like crumbs in your bra during a Zoom meeting. Second, you need a friend who will help you hide the evidence when you accidentally break your neighbor’s garden gnome and then bring you ice cream to soothe your guilty conscience, which is why you’re at the top of this recipe (you’re the “emergency alibi + dessert” component). Third, you need one completely useless hobby that makes you unreasonably happy—mine is collecting rubber ducks that wear tiny cowboy hats, and yours could be learning to yodel or collecting vintage lunch boxes from the 80s. Fourth, you need to stop listening to your cousin Karen’s advice about “adulting” because she still thinks TikTok is a type of salad dressing and her idea of a good time is organizing her sock drawer by color. Fifth, you need to take naps that last longer than a Netflix episode, because sleep is the only free luxury we have left and if you skip it, the universe will punish you with a case of the Mondays that lasts all week. Sixth, you need to allow yourself to laugh at the stupid stuff—like when you trip over your own feet in the grocery store, or when your dog steals your sandwich and runs away with it, because those are the moments that make life feel worth living. Seventh, you need to stop trying to be perfect, because perfect is boring and the most interesting people are the ones who have stories about accidentally dyeing their hair neon green or burning down a batch of cookies. Eighth, you need to call me this weekend so we can test out this recipe by eating cheese puffs, watching bad movies, and making fun of Karen’s sock drawer obsession—no excuses, unless your rubber duck cowboy collection needs emergency grooming, which I’ll totally understand.

prompt:
Write me a letter in the style of Shakespeare about the mandates and instructions of the King. The letter should be in Markdown.

You do not need to include a title for your response.
response:
> To our trusty and well-beloved Lord Edmund of the Northern Marches, Keeper of the Frost-Gates and Defender of Our Northern Realm,
>
> Greetings and grace be unto thee, as we sit upon our royal throne and reflect upon the steadfast service thou hast rendered to our realm these past seven years. The northern winds blow cold, and with them come not only frost but the murmurings of discontent that creep like shadows into our villages. Thus, we charge thee with these **royal mandates**, to be fulfilled with all haste and diligence, lest our realm fall prey to chaos or foe:
>
> **First, the defense of our borders:** Let thy watchtowers stand as sentinels against the raiders of the Highlands, who like wolves in the night do steal our sheep and burn our homesteads. Post double guards during the dark of the moon, when the eye of man doth fail, and let every watchman carry a horn to sound the alarm at the first sign of foe. He who slumbers at his post shall feel the weight of our displeasure, for a realm unguarded is a crown undone. Reinforce the Frost-Gates with oak and iron, and see that no breach be left for the enemy to exploit.
>
> **Second, the gathering of the grain tithe:** One third of this year’s harvest shall be gathered from every manor and farm within thy domain, and stored in the royal granaries at Carlisle. Winter’s breath doth draw nigh, and the poor shall cry for bread if our stores be empty. Let not the greedy hoard what is meant for the hungry; for a king’s justice is not in filling his own larder, but in feeding his people as a father feeds his children. Any lord who withholds his tithe shall be summoned to our court to answer for his greed.
>
> **Third, the administration of equal justice:** Convene a public assize in every market town within thy charge, once each moon, that the grievances of the commons may be heard. Let the scales of justice hang even: the rich man’s gold shall not buy him favor, nor the poor man’s rags condemn him. Punish the thief with stripes, the murderer with death, but spare the man who steals only to feed his starving babe. For mercy is the crown’s brightest jewel, and cruelty doth tarnish even the purest of reigns.
>
> **Fourth, the suppression of treasonous dissent:** Root out any who speak treason against our crown, but be not hasty to condemn. Idle gossip in the alehouse is but the froth of a fool’s cup, but he who plots to raise a banner against us shall be bound in irons and brought to our court to answer for his crimes. Let thy spies walk among the people, but let them not be cruel; for a king who fears his people is a king without honor.
>
> Know this, Lord Edmund: thy faithfulness shall not go unrewarded. Fulfill these mandates, and we shall grant thee the manor of Blackthorn, with all its lands and rents, as a token of our gratitude. But neglect them, and thou shalt lose not only our favor, but thy place in our council. We send thee our royal seal, affixed to this missive, that all men may know these words are our own.
>
> May the grace of God guide thee, and may thy sword remain sharp in our service.
>
> Thy Sovereign Lord,
> **King Alaric the Third**
> By the Grace of God, King of Albion and Lord of the Isles
> Given at our Palace of Windsor, on the 15th day of October, in the tenth year of our reign.
> *Sealed with the Great Seal of Albion*

prompt:
Explain to me how to ride a bike like I am a kid.

Your response must include the keywords "slow", "like" and "kid" at least once each.
response: To ride a bike, start by picking a flat, open area like an empty driveway or quiet park—avoid busy roads while you’re getting the hang of it. Adjust your bike’s seat so your feet can reach the ground when you sit; this gives you a stable base if you need to stop suddenly. Ask someone you trust to stand behind you, holding the back of the seat to keep you upright as you begin. Place your feet on the pedals, push off gently, and start pedaling slow—resist the urge to speed up right away, since balance comes from steady, controlled movement. Keep your eyes focused ahead on the path, not your feet; this helps you maintain your direction. After a minute or two, the person holding the seat can let go slowly. Even if you wobble or tip over, don’t get discouraged—every kid learning to ride a bike experiences those small setbacks, and each one helps you learn how to shift your weight and stay balanced. Before you know it, you’ll be coasting smoothly, feeling the wind on your cheeks just like you dreamed you would.

{"pitch": "Startup Pitch: Tipperary – The App That Takes the Guesswork Out of Tipping

1. Hook & Problem Statement
Good morning, investors. 68% of U.S. diners report feeling anxious about tipping, and 41% admit to overtipping just to avoid awkward social interactions. Generic tip calculators offer one-size-fits-all percentages, but they ignore critical context: a 20% tip at a fast-casual spot may be excessive, while at a fine-dining restaurant, it’s the minimum. Travelers face even more uncertainty—what’s the norm in a new city? Even servers lack transparency into how their peers’ average tips compare to their own. Right now, there’s no centralized, verified source for restaurant-specific tip data. That’s where Tipperary comes in.

2. Solution: Tipperary App
Tipperary is the first mobile app dedicated to crowdsourcing and aggregating real, verified tip data to give diners and servers actionable, context-rich insights. Our mission is to eliminate tipping anxiety and create transparency between diners, servers, and restaurants.

3. Product Overview
Key features include:
- Verified Tip Submissions: Users confirm visits via receipt upload or reservation links to ensure data accuracy, eliminating fake submissions.
- Restaurant Tip Profiles: For every venue, view average tips broken down by service type (dine-in, takeout), time of day, party size, and service quality ratings.
- Custom Tip Calculator: Tailors recommendations to the restaurant’s average tip range, not just generic percentages.
- Personalized Alerts: For premium users, get notifications about restaurants where tips are trending up (ideal for servers) or down (helpful for budget-conscious diners).
- B2B Restaurant Dashboard: For partner venues, access analytics on tip trends to inform service adjustments or clear tipping guidelines.

4. Market Opportunity
- TAM: 150M frequent U.S. diners (per National Restaurant Association data), plus 2.7M restaurant servers.
- SAM: 30M diners who regularly use mobile apps to plan dining experiences.
- SOM: 5M users within 2 years of full launch.
Competitive Gap: No direct competitors exist. Generic tip calculators lack context, and review platforms like Yelp only offer anecdotal tip mentions, not structured, verified data. Tipperary fills a unique, unmet need.

5. Business Model
- Freemium: Free version includes basic search and calculator; premium ($4.99/month) offers ad-free browsing, personalized alerts, and advanced analytics.
- B2B Partnerships: Charge restaurants $99–$299/month for access to the Tipperary Insights Dashboard, which provides trend analysis and peer benchmarking.
- Affiliate Revenue: Earn commissions from links to reservation apps like OpenTable and Resy.

6. Traction
- Beta Launch: Piloted in NYC, Chicago, and Austin with 15,000 users and 50,000 verified tip submissions.
- User Satisfaction: 4.8/5 average rating on Apple App Store and Google Play, with 92% of users reporting reduced tipping anxiety.
- Restaurant Partnerships: 20 local venues joined our pilot insights program, with one fine-dining spot reporting a 12% drop in customer complaints about tipping confusion.

7. Team
- CEO: Jane Doe, 5 years in food tech (previously led operations at a meal-kit startup) with deep connections to restaurant owners.
- CTO: John Smith, 7 years in mobile app development and data aggregation, specializing in user-generated content verification algorithms.
- Head of Community: Maria Garcia, 10 years in restaurant operations (former server and floor manager), with expertise in building trust between diners and service staff.

8. Call to Action
We’re seeking $500,000 in seed funding to:
- Expand to 10 additional U.S. cities within 12 months.
- Scale targeted marketing campaigns to reach 100,000 users by year-end.
- Enhance our data verification algorithms to reduce fraud by 20%.
- Launch the full B2B Insights Dashboard for restaurant partners.
With your investment, Tipperary will become the go-to platform for tipping transparency, transforming how diners, servers, and restaurants interact around one of the most stressful parts of dining out. Thank you."}
