prompt:
Improve the following text, which is about how to learn a language. Also, provide two alternatives. The text is: "The best way to learn about a new culture is by living in it. Learn a new language by living in a country where it is spoken, and you'll be able to speak the language like a native in no time!".

End your response with "Please let me know if you have other questions." No other words should follow this sentence.
response:
### Improved Text
The most impactful way to both learn about a new culture and master its language is through immersive, day-to-day living in the country where it’s spoken. Unlike textbook or classroom learning, which often prioritizes formal grammar and vocabulary, living abroad plunges you into real-world interactions—casual chats with local baristas, neighborhood potlucks, and routine errands—that expose you to colloquialisms, natural intonation, and cultural context. This constant, unfiltered exposure accelerates your progress, allowing you to speak the language with the fluency, authenticity, and natural rhythm of a native in a surprisingly short time.

### Alternative 1
If you’re determined to learn a new language and truly connect with its culture, full immersion is the golden ticket. Relocate to a place where the language is woven into every aspect of daily life: every trip to the grocery store becomes a vocabulary lesson, every casual conversation with a neighbor hones your listening skills, and every local festival teaches you the cultural stories behind phrases. Before you know it, you’ll be dropping colloquial slang like a local, understanding subtle tone shifts, and speaking with the kind of fluency that makes people ask, “Wait, are you sure you’re not a native?”

### Alternative 2
Immersive living isn’t just a great way to learn a culture—it’s the fastest path to speaking a new language like a native. Even a short-term stay (think 2–3 months) in a country where your target language is spoken can transform your skills. You’ll stop translating from your native tongue and start thinking in the language itself, pick up on conversational cues you’d never find in a textbook, and build confidence through daily practice. By the time you return home, you’ll have a level of fluency and cultural insight that years of classroom learning could never match.

He could also store the surplus in climate-controlled silos, root cellars, or freezers to use for his family’s meals during the off-season or save seeds from the healthiest plants for next year’s planting cycle. prompt:
Write an email to your friend about what triggers you.

Your response must be wrapped in single quotation marks.
response:
'
Subject: A little something I wanted to share with you

Hey Sam,

Hope your week’s been going okay—missed our usual coffee chat last Tuesday, so I’ve been looking forward to catching up properly. I’ve been thinking about some stuff lately, and since you’re one of the people I trust most, I wanted to open up about what triggers me, just so you have a heads-up.

First off, when someone interrupts me mid-sentence, especially if I’m trying to talk about something that feels important or vulnerable. It makes me feel like my words don’t matter, and I end up shutting down because I don’t think anyone’s really listening. I know conversations can get lively, but it’s something that’s been hitting me harder lately, and I wanted you to know.

Then, when people dismiss my feelings by saying things like “it’s not that big a deal” or “you’re overreacting.” I’ve always struggled with feeling like my emotions are valid, and when someone says that, it makes me feel small and like I shouldn’t bother sharing how I’m really doing. It’s not that I need everyone to agree with me—just that they’ll let me feel what I feel without judgment.

Also, last-minute plans that completely throw off my routine. I’m someone who needs a little time to adjust to changes, and if I get a text at 4 PM saying “let’s go out tonight” when I was planning a quiet night in with a book, my anxiety spikes and I feel overwhelmed. I know it’s not personal, but it’s hard for me to switch gears that fast.

I don’t want you to walk on eggshells around me or anything—this is just me being honest about what affects me. If any of these things happen accidentally, I’ll try to communicate it calmly, and I hope you can understand. And of course, I’m always here to listen if you want to share your triggers too.

Wanna grab that coffee this Saturday? I’d love to hear how your new job’s going and chat more about this if you want.

Take care,
Jesse
'

prompt:
Translate the following sentence into German and then criticize it: Werner was a good friend of mine, but not very smart.

Your response must contain the word "schlau" at least once.
response:
### Übersetzung:
Werner war ein guter Freund von mir, aber nicht sehr intelligent.

### Kritik:
Diese Aussage ist reduktionistisch und unreflektiert. Zum einen reduziert sie die gesamte Persönlichkeit Werners auf eine einzelne kognitive Eigenschaft, obwohl sie gleichzeitig anerkennt, dass er ein guter Freund war. Gute Freundschaften basieren nicht darauf, ob jemand schlau ist oder nicht – vielmehr zählen Eigenschaften wie Vertrauen, Zuverlässigkeit und die Fähigkeit, anderen in schwierigen Zeiten beizustehen, die weitaus wichtiger für eine erfüllende Beziehung sind. Zum anderen ist die Bewertung „nicht sehr intelligent“ extrem vage: Sie gibt keine konkreten Hinweise darauf, ob es um schulische Leistungen, praktisches Geschick oder soziale Kompetenz geht. Indem man hier eine so oberflächliche Beurteilung abgibt, riskiert man, die positiven Aspekte der Beziehung zu übergehen und Werner als Person zu verkümmern. Insgesamt ist die Aussage unhöflich in ihrer Einfachheit, weil sie eine wertvolle menschliche Verbindung durch eine flüchtige, unklare Bewertung überdeckt, statt die Stärken der Freundschaft zu betonen.

prompt:
Which was the better team in the 1987-88 season: Tottenham Hotspur or Stockton?

Your answer must be exactly 4 paragraphs where paragraphs are separated by a single new line. The third paragraph must start with the word "Stockton". Your response must not include the keywords "gao" and "hearts". Do not add a postscript at the end of your response.
response:
Comparing Tottenham Hotspur and Stockton in the 1987-88 season requires framing the question around competitive context, as the two teams operated in vastly different tiers of English football. Tottenham competed in the First Division, the top flight at the time, and while they had a squad with established talent—including former top scorers and international players—their campaign was largely underwhelming. They finished 13th in the league table, well outside European qualification spots, and were knocked out of the FA Cup in the quarter-finals by eventual winners Wimbledon. Consistency eluded them, with a mix of impressive wins against top sides and disappointing losses to mid-table and lower-ranked opponents.

Stockton, by contrast, plied their trade in the Northern League Division One, a semi-professional tier several rungs below the First Division. Their 1987-88 season was far more successful relative to their competition. They topped the league table by a comfortable margin, securing the Northern League title with a high win percentage and scoring more goals than any other team in the division. They also had a strong run in the FA Vase, reaching the later rounds and gaining recognition for their attacking style of play. For a semi-professional side with limited resources, this level of achievement marked a standout campaign.

Stockton’s dominance in their own league highlights a key distinction between the two teams’ seasons. While Tottenham’s squad had greater individual talent and access to better resources, they failed to translate that into consistent results against top-flight competition. Stockton, on the other hand, maximized their potential, leveraging team cohesion and tactical discipline to outperform every other side in their division. Their success was a testament to effective management and a unified squad, even if it came against less formidable opposition than Tottenham faced.

Determining which was the "better" team ultimately depends on the criteria used. If judging by overall squad quality and the ability to compete against the highest level of English football, Tottenham holds the edge, as their players were tested against the likes of Liverpool and Manchester United. However, if measuring success relative to their respective leagues and the ability to achieve set goals, Stockton was the more successful team in 1987-88. Neither can be definitively called "better" across the board, but each team’s season tells a story of performance in their own unique competitive space.

prompt:
Write a blog post about how to train a dog that is geared towards kids.

Your response must not include the keywords "finale" and "less".
response:
# How to Train Your Dog (For Kids Who Love Their Pup!)  

Hey there, dog lovers! If you’ve ever wanted to teach your furry friend cool tricks or just help them be the best pup around, training is the way to go. It’s not just about showing off—training helps you and your dog understand each other better, and it’s super fun too! Let’s dive into easy steps you can follow to train your dog like a pro.  

First things first: Ask a grown-up for help before you start. They can make sure your dog is in a happy mood (no training when they’re grumpy or tired!) and help you stay safe. Grown-ups also know your dog’s favorite treats, which are key to grabbing their attention fast.  

Next, pick simple tricks to start with. “Sit” is a great first one. Here’s how to do it: Hold a tiny, yummy treat close to your dog’s nose, then slowly lift it over their head. As they follow the treat, their bottom will naturally touch the floor. The second that happens, say “Sit!” clearly and give them the treat right away. Don’t forget to cheer and pet them too—dogs love hearing how awesome they are!  

Another fun trick is “Shake.” Once your dog knows how to sit, hold out your hand in front of them and say “Shake.” If they don’t put their paw on your hand, gently lift one of their paws (softly, don’t pull!) and wrap your hand around it. Then give the treat and praise. After a few times, they’ll start putting their paw out on their own, excited for that tasty reward.  

Remember, training sessions should be quick and happy. Dogs have short attention spans, so 5 to 10 minutes at a time is perfect. Do it when your dog is awake and playful—right after breakfast or before a walk is usually a good time. If they start wandering off or getting bored, it’s okay to stop and try again later.  

Patience is your best friend here. Your dog might not get a trick on the first try, and that’s totally okay! I remember when my puppy, Max, took three whole days to learn how to sit. I almost gave up, but then one morning, he did it all by himself, and I gave him three treats (shhh, don’t tell my mom!). Now he sits every time I ask, even when there’s no treat around.  

Practice every day, even just a little bit. Consistency helps your dog remember what you want them to do. Soon enough, you can move on to fancier tricks like “Roll Over” or “Play Dead.” Imagine how cool it will be to show your friends your dog’s new skills at your next backyard playdate!  

Most importantly, always be kind to your dog. Never yell at them if they make a mistake—they’re just learning, like you do when you’re trying a new math problem or sport. Training is all about building a stronger bond with your pup, so make sure every moment is full of love and fun.  

So grab your dog’s favorite treats, call your grown-up, and start training today. Before you know it, your furry best friend will be doing all sorts of awesome tricks, and you’ll be the proudest kid on the block!

prompt:
Which of the following is a better way to describe supporting ecological landscapes: (A) the practice of using the natural features of a landscape to create a more sustainable environment, or (B) the practice of using the natural features of a landscape to create a more aesthetically pleasing environment?

Your response should be in all lowercase letters. Your response should contain at least 3 commas. Your response should be more than 20 sentences.
response: option a is the better way to describe supporting ecological landscapes, because it centers the core purpose of such practices, which is to prioritize the health and longevity of natural systems. when we talk about supporting ecological landscapes, our primary goal should be to work with nature rather than against it, and option a directly reflects that mindset. aesthetic appeal can be a nice side effect of sustainable landscape practices, but it should not be the main focus, as ecological health is far more critical for the planet’s future. supporting ecological landscapes means considering how every choice impacts local wildlife, soil health, water retention, and carbon sequestration, all of which are key components of a sustainable environment. option b’s focus on aesthetically pleasing environments risks reducing these landscapes to mere decorative elements, ignoring their vital role in supporting biodiversity and mitigating climate change. for example, a landscape designed solely for aesthetics might prioritize non-native, high-maintenance plants that look pretty but provide no food or shelter for local pollinators, which are essential for crop production and ecosystem balance. in contrast, a landscape designed with sustainability in mind would use native plants that are adapted to the local climate, require less water and fertilizer, and support a wide range of native species. this approach helps to maintain natural food webs, prevent soil erosion, and reduce the use of harmful chemicals that can leach into water sources. when we frame supporting ecological landscapes around sustainability, we encourage practices that benefit both humans and the natural world, creating spaces that are resilient to climate change and support long-term ecological balance. option a also aligns with global conservation efforts, which increasingly emphasize working with natural features to restore degraded ecosystems and protect vulnerable species. many communities are now adopting sustainable landscape practices to combat issues like urban heat islands, which can be mitigated by using trees and green spaces that provide shade and cool the air. these practices not only create a more sustainable environment but also improve human health by reducing air pollution and providing access to green spaces that promote mental well-being. while an aesthetically pleasing landscape can boost property values or make a space more inviting, these benefits are short-term compared to the long-term gains of a sustainable environment. option b’s narrow focus on aesthetics might lead to practices that are harmful in the long run, such as overwatering lawns or using invasive plant species that outcompete native plants. supporting ecological landscapes is not just about making a space look nice; it’s about nurturing the natural processes that keep our planet healthy. option a captures this holistic view, recognizing that the natural features of a landscape are tools to support ecological function, not just to create visual appeal. every time we choose to work with natural features for sustainability, we are contributing to a larger movement to protect our planet for future generations. this approach also encourages education and awareness, as people learn about the importance of native plants, soil health, and water conservation through their landscape choices. in contrast, focusing solely on aesthetics might lead people to overlook the complex ecological interactions that make a landscape truly functional and beneficial. when we describe supporting ecological landscapes using option a, we set a clear, meaningful goal that guides our actions toward positive environmental impact. this goal helps to ensure that our landscape practices are not just superficial but have a lasting, positive effect on the environment. it also helps to connect individual landscape choices to broader ecological issues, showing how small actions can add up to make a big difference. even if a sustainable landscape doesn’t look as "perfect" as one designed solely for aesthetics, its benefits far outweigh any minor visual drawbacks, as it supports the health of the planet and all its inhabitants. option a’s focus on sustainability also encourages innovation, as people find new ways to use natural features like rain gardens, swales, and permeable pavements to manage water runoff and reduce flooding. these practices not only create a more sustainable environment but also help to protect communities from the impacts of extreme weather events, which are becoming more frequent due to climate change. in the end, supporting ecological landscapes is about respecting and working with nature, not reshaping it to fit our narrow ideas of beauty. option a perfectly encapsulates this ethos, making it the far better way to describe these important practices. option b’s focus on aesthetics misses the point of what ecological landscape support is truly about, reducing a vital environmental practice to a matter of personal taste rather than a necessary action for planetary health.

prompt:
What do prehistoric megaliths in Europe look like?

Please give exactly two different responses, separated by 3 pound signs: ###. Include all of the following keywords: 'BC', 'culture', and 'prehistoric' in the response.
response:
Prehistoric megaliths in Europe take on a range of striking forms, from the iconic circular stone circles of Stonehenge in England to the low, stone-covered dolmens scattered across Ireland and France. Constructed between 4500 and 1200 BC, these massive structures were the work of a prehistoric culture that relied on communal effort to transport and erect stones weighing several tons, often over long distances. Many served as burial sites or ritual hubs, aligned with celestial events to mark seasonal changes and honor ancestral beliefs.
###
Across different regions of Europe, prehistoric megaliths reflect the unique traditions of the local culture that built them. In Portugal, the Almendres Cromlech boasts more than 90 standing stones arranged in concentric circles, erected around 3000 BC by a community that used the site for astronomical observations and spiritual gatherings. In Scandinavia, passage graves—megalithic structures with narrow stone corridors leading to inner chambers—were built around 3500 BC, designed to hold the remains of multiple generations and symbolize the connection between the living and the dead. Each megalith stands as a testament to the ingenuity and shared values of prehistoric peoples who left no written records of their lives.

response:
Write a summary of the plot of 'The Great Gatsby' in the style of a tabloid newspaper. Paraphrase the request in your own words before giving your answer. Add a greeting phrase like 'Hello,' or 'Hi there,' before the paraphrased request.

Hi there, you’d like me to summarize the plot of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s *The Great Gatsby* using the sensational, gossipy tone of a tabloid newspaper, and I need to restate this request in my own words before sharing the summary.

**HEADLINE: MYSTERIOUS WEST EGG MILLIONAIRE’S LOVE OBSESSION ENDS IN DOUBLE MURDER-SUICIDE! EXCLUSIVE DETAILS OF THE SCANDAL THAT ROCKED LONG ISLAND!**  
Subhead: Lavish parties, secret affairs, and a fatal car crash unmask the tragic truth behind Jay Gatsby’s glittering facade!

LONG ISLAND, NY—Neighbors of the enigmatic Jay Gatsby, the reclusive tycoon who threw weekly ragers drawing A-listers, social climbers, and party crashers by the hundreds, are reeling after a shocking weekend of violence that left two men dead and a town whispering.

Sources close to Gatsby’s next-door neighbor, Nick Carraway (a quiet Yale grad spilling all the tea), reveal Gatsby’s opulent mansion and nonstop soirees were a ruse: he was desperate to win back long-lost love Daisy Buchanan, a privileged socialite trapped in a loveless marriage to brute millionaire Tom Buchanan.

Tom, who’s been carrying on a torrid affair with Myrtle Wilson—a fiery redhead from the gritty Valley of Ashes, married to gas station owner George—didn’t take kindly to Gatsby’s advances. The two clashed in an explosive hotel showdown, where Tom dropped a bombshell: Gatsby’s fortune wasn’t legitimate—it was dirty cash from bootlegging and shady side deals!

Daisy, caught in the crossfire, fled in Gatsby’s sleek yellow roadster. In a panic, she plowed into Myrtle, killing her instantly. But instead of taking blame, Tom hatched a cruel lie: he told grief-stricken George that Gatsby was behind the wheel.

The next morning, George stormed Gatsby’s mansion and found him floating in his pool, still dreaming of a future with Daisy. A single gunshot rang out—Gatsby was dead, and George turned the gun on himself moments later.

The scandal doesn’t end there! At Gatsby’s funeral, only Nick and a handful of strangers showed up. Daisy and Tom? They skipped town, leaving the man who’d spent years chasing his dream to rot in obscurity.

“Gatsby loved Daisy more than his own life,” Nick told our reporters through tears. “But she was just a selfish rich girl who couldn’t be bothered to even say goodbye.”

EXCLUSIVE BONUS: Rumor has it Gatsby’s real name was James Gatz, a poor farm boy who reinvented himself to impress the woman who got away. What a tragic fall from grace!

prompt:
Is Grafton, Vermont a good place to live?

The first paragraph of your response must start with the word "Grafton".
response:
Grafton, Vermont is widely regarded as a wonderful place to live for those who cherish small-town charm, natural beauty, and a tight-knit community. Nestled in the rolling hills of Windham County, the town is known for its postcard-perfect scenery—think covered bridges winding over babbling brooks, vibrant fall foliage that paints the landscape in gold and crimson, and snow-dusted meadows in winter. Local institutions like the Grafton Cheese Company and the historic Grafton Inn anchor the downtown area, while community events such as the annual Harvest Festival and weekly farmers’ markets foster strong connections between residents. Low crime rates and a focus on preserving the town’s historic character make it an ideal spot for families, retirees, and anyone seeking a slower, more intentional way of life.


That said, Grafton isn’t without its drawbacks, particularly for those accustomed to urban conveniences or needing access to a diverse job market. The local economy is heavily rooted in tourism, agriculture, and small businesses, so career opportunities in fields like tech, finance, or specialized healthcare are limited—many residents commute to larger nearby towns like Brattleboro or Keene, New Hampshire, for work. Winters can be long and harsh, with heavy snowfall that may disrupt daily routines, and amenities like big-box stores, advanced medical facilities, or diverse dining options are scarce, requiring trips to neighboring areas. For those who crave bustling nightlife, cultural diversity, or quick access to major cities, Grafton’s quiet pace might feel isolating.


Ultimately, whether Grafton is a good place to live depends on your personal priorities. If you value waking up to views of green hills, knowing your neighbors by name, and spending weekends hiking, skiing, or exploring local trails, it’s an exceptional choice. Remote workers who can set up their offices from home will find the town’s peaceful environment conducive to productivity, while retirees can enjoy a calm, safe community with plenty of outdoor activities to stay active. For anyone looking to escape the chaos of city life and embrace a more nature-centric, community-focused existence, Grafton offers a quality of life that’s hard to find elsewhere.

prompt:
Write a poem about a lonely Hue. The poem should be written for teenagers.

Your response should not include any italicized text. Your response should not contain the word "singles".
response:
**Lonely Hue**  

The art room shelf’s a pecking order—  
neon pink struts, sunflower yellow preens,  
crimson’s the loud one who steals the spotlight.  
Hue’s the faded indigo, squeezed at the tube’s end,  
cap cracked, label peeling like a scab no one picks.  

At lunch, Hue slumps in the back booth,  
hood up, phone face-down (last text: “u coming?”  
sent three days ago, still no reply).  
The table next to them’s a storm of inside jokes,  
fries passed like secrets, and Hue’s the ketchup packet  
no one bothered to tear open.  

After school, Hue walks the sidewalk where  
oak trees drip rain like unspoken apologies.  
Friends post selfies in the park—  
grins sharp as new crayons, arms slung over shoulders—  
Hue scrolls past, thumb hovering,  
then locks the screen. The sky’s the same indigo  
as their chipped nail polish, but no one says,  
“Hey, that’s your color.”  

Tonight, Hue sits on the windowsill,  
dabs a finger in the leftover paint,  
draws a small star on the fogged glass.  
It’s not perfect, not bright, not the kind  
that gets reposted or liked.  
But it’s theirs—  
a lonely hue, glowing slow,  
waiting for someone to stop  
and really see the blue.

prompt:
Tulsa is a professional dog walker. Write a description for Tulsa's day-to-day work.

Your response must have at least 8 sentences.
response: Tulsa’s day starts before the sun rises, at 5:30 a.m., when she brews a strong cup of coffee and reviews her digital schedule, noting each dog’s name, breed, special needs, and preferred walking route. By 6:15 a.m., she’s lacing up her waterproof boots and grabbing her gear bag—stocked with waste bags, extra leashes, a portable water bowl, and treats for good behavior—before heading to her first client’s home in the quiet, tree-lined neighborhood nearby. Her first walk is with Max, a rambunctious golden retriever who can’t wait to bound out the door, so she takes him to the local park where he can chase squirrels and play fetch for 45 minutes, stopping every few minutes to let him drink water and catch his breath. Next, she visits Mrs. Henderson’s apartment to walk Bella, a tiny Chihuahua with a bad knee, so she sticks to the flat sidewalks around the building, moving at a slow, steady pace and pausing often to let Bella sniff at fire hydrants and greet passing cats. By mid-morning, Tulsa has three more walks scheduled: a pair of energetic border collies who need a long hike on the wooded trail, a shy rescue dog named Luna who prefers quiet streets with few people, and an elderly basset hound who only wants to meander around his backyard and nap in the sun for a bit. Between walks, she sends quick updates to each client—including photos or short videos of their dogs having fun—so they can feel at ease while they’re at work or running errands. Around noon, she takes a 30-minute break to eat a packed lunch at a bench in the park, scrolling through messages from new clients inquiring about her services and responding to any questions about her rates or availability. In the afternoon, she focuses on clients who work late, walking a playful poodle who loves to stop and say hello to every stranger they meet, and a large Great Dane who needs gentle exercise to keep his joints healthy. Before wrapping up her day at 5 p.m., she makes one final stop to check on a client’s puppy who’s too young for long walks, spending 20 minutes playing with him in the backyard and reinforcing basic commands like “sit” and “stay” with small, healthy treats. By the time she gets home, her feet are sore, but she can’t help but smile as she scrolls through the happy replies from clients, knowing she’s not just walking dogs—she’s providing peace of mind to busy owners and joy to the furry friends who depend on her.

prompt:
Write a casual summary of the U.S. maternity leave policy.

Your response should have three sections (Part A, Part B, and Part C). Your response should contain no more than 20 sentences.
response:
### Part A
The only nationwide maternity leave policy in the U.S. is the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), which just offers unpaid time off. To qualify, you need to have worked at your company for at least a year, logged 1,250 hours that year, and work at a site with 50+ employees within 75 miles. If you check all those boxes, you get 12 weeks of unpaid leave, and your employer has to hold your job (or a similar role) for you when you come back. But this leaves out millions—about 40% of U.S. workers don’t qualify because their company is too small or they haven’t put in enough hours.

### Part B
A handful of states have stepped in to offer better maternity leave options, usually paid ones. States like California, New York, and Washington run paid family leave programs funded by employee (and sometimes employer) payroll taxes. These programs give anywhere from 6 to 12 weeks of paid leave, with benefits based on a percentage of your salary (capped at a certain amount so high earners don’t get a huge payout). Some states also require employers to offer extra unpaid leave beyond FMLA, but this varies a ton from place to place. For example, Massachusetts has a paid leave program that covers up to 12 weeks at 80% of your salary (up to a weekly cap).

### Part C
Many big companies, especially in tech or finance, offer their own paid maternity leave as a fancy perk to attract top talent. These can range from 12 weeks of fully paid leave to even longer—some companies give 6 months or more, often with added bonuses like flexible return-to-work plans or lactation support. But small businesses almost never offer this, since it’s super expensive and not required by law. At the end of the day, maternity leave in the U.S. is a total patchwork: your experience depends entirely on where you live and who you work for.

prompt:
Please elaborate on the following text: "It's not a bug, it's a feature!"

Your response should contain exactly 3 bullet points in markdown format. Use "-" to indicate a bullet point.
response:
- This phrase originated as a tongue-in-cheek retort in early computing circles, where developers would reframe unintended glitches as deliberate design choices to deflect criticism. A famous early example dates to the 1960s, when an IBM mainframe’s tendency to crash under certain conditions was initially dismissed as a feature meant to prevent data corruption—even though the crash was unplanned.
- In modern product development and marketing, the phrase is often used strategically to reposition perceived flaws as unique value propositions. For instance, a handmade furniture brand might frame a slightly uneven table leg as an "artisanal signature" rather than a manufacturing error, turning a potential negative into a selling point that resonates with consumers seeking one-of-a-kind items.
- It also underscores the tension between user expectations and technical constraints: what feels like a bug to an end user is sometimes a deliberate trade-off made by developers to prioritize other critical features. For example, a mobile app’s slower load time might be intentional to minimize data usage for users with limited plans, even if it frustrates those with high-speed internet access.

prompt:
A young couple that just got married is going to Seattle for two days. They're flying from New York. Could you write them an itinerary? Please make sure that all punctuations are legit.

Your response should use more than 15 sentences.
response:
### 2-Day Romantic Seattle Itinerary for Newlyweds  

Day 1: Waterfront Magic & Sunset Vibes  
1. After landing at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, grab your bags and hop into a cozy Uber to The Edgewater, a waterfront hotel with rooms overlooking Puget Sound—perfect for quiet moments watching the waves.  
2. Drop off your luggage, then walk 10 minutes to Stumptown Coffee Roasters’ Capitol Hill location, where you can fuel up with a creamy latte and a flaky almond croissant, a warm introduction to Seattle’s coffee culture.  
3. Next, meander to Pike Place Market, where you’ll laugh at fishmongers tossing salmon between stalls and stop to pick up a small bouquet of fresh peonies for your hotel room.  
4. Don’t skip the original Starbucks store at 1912 Pike Place; snap a photo together in front of the iconic green-and-white sign and grab a souvenir mug to remember the trip.  
5. For lunch, share a bowl of clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl at Pike Place Chowder, a local favorite that’s been serving rich, creamy chowder for decades.  
6. After lunch, ride the Seattle Great Wheel during golden hour, when the sun glints off the water and turns the sky soft orange.  
7. Stroll through the Olympic Sculpture Park next, a free outdoor museum where you can admire large-scale art while walking along Elliott Bay’s shoreline.  
8. As dusk falls, head to The Walrus and the Carpenter in Ballard, a cozy oyster bar, for a romantic dinner of fresh oysters, grilled octopus, and a bottle of crisp Washington white wine.  
9. End the day with a sunset cruise on Puget Sound; many small-group cruises let you watch the sky turn pink, spot harbor seals, and even listen to live acoustic music.  

Day 2: Skyline Views & Local Flavors  
10. Wake up early and walk to Oddfellows Café + Bar in Capitol Hill for a leisurely breakfast—try their famous ricotta hotcakes or a savory breakfast sandwich, paired with freshly squeezed orange juice.  
11. Grab an Uber to Kerry Park in Queen Anne, where you’ll capture that classic Seattle skyline photo with Mount Rainier towering in the background (fingers crossed for clear skies!).  
12. Next, visit the Space Needle; book the “Glass Floor Experience” for a thrilling walk over the transparent floor 500 feet above the ground, then soak in 360-degree views from the observation deck.  
13. For lunch, share meze plates at Mamnoon, a nearby Middle Eastern spot, where you can sample hummus, falafel, and spiced lamb skewers.  
14. Walk to the Seattle Art Museum (SAM) afterward, and spend an hour exploring its impressive Native American art collection and modern masterpieces.  
15. Wander through Pioneer Square next, Seattle’s oldest neighborhood, where you can admire cobblestone streets, historic brick buildings, and visit the Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park.  
16. Late afternoon, head to Fremont Brewing in the quirky Fremont neighborhood; sample a flight of award-winning IPAs or a smooth stout, and sit in their sunlit beer garden if the weather is warm.  
17. For your final dinner, book a table at Lark, a beloved farm-to-table restaurant in Capitol Hill, where you can share small plates of locally sourced ingredients like roasted carrots with harissa and seared scallops.  
18. End the trip with a scoop of Molly Moon’s Homemade Ice Cream—try salted caramel or honey lavender—while walking along the waterfront and reflecting on your first trip as a married couple.  
19. Before heading to the airport, swing by a local bookstore like Elliott Bay Book Company to pick up a travel journal or a novel set in Seattle, a memento of your romantic getaway.

prompt:
I've got a collection of military insignia that I'd like to get rid of, but I don't know how. Can you help me?

Give exactly two different responses, separating them with 3 dash lines (---). You do not need to include a title for your response. Your response must not contain the keywords "adoption" and "carriage".
response:
Start with getting a quick sense of your collection’s value by reaching out to a local military history museum or joining online military insignia collector groups; members can help identify rare pieces or those with provenance that might fetch a higher price. Next, contact specialized military memorabilia shops in your area—many will buy pieces outright or offer consignment to sell them on your behalf. If you’d rather donate than sell, consider local veteran organizations, JROTC programs, or small military museums; these groups often use insignia to educate others about military history, giving your collection a purposeful new home. You can also post detailed photos (including any markings or dates) on dedicated collector forums, where enthusiasts frequently seek out specific insignia for their own collections.
---
For a straightforward sale, list your insignia on general online marketplaces like eBay or Etsy, categorizing them under military memorabilia and including clear descriptions of each piece’s era, branch of service, and condition. You could also look for regional military collector shows in your area; these events bring together dozens of dedicated buyers, and setting up a small table (or even just networking with attendees) can lead to quick, in-person sales. If some pieces are damaged or have no collector value, avoid tossing them in the trash—check with local scrap metal facilities if they contain metal components, or reach out to military history groups to see if they can repurpose parts for educational displays. Even common insignia might hold sentimental value for someone with ties to the service branch, so posting on community Facebook groups for veterans or military families could also yield interest.

prompt:
Please give me some recommendations for good books about the history of the United States.

Your response should be completely in English, no other language is allowed.
response:
Here are curated recommendations for exceptional books on U.S. history, spanning diverse perspectives and eras:

1. **A People's History of the United States** by Howard Zinn  
   A radical, bottom-up reexamination of U.S. history that centers marginalized groups—enslaved people, Indigenous communities, working-class Americans, women, and activists—rather than political and economic elites. From Columbus’s arrival to the late 20th century, it challenges traditional narratives and amplifies voices often erased in standard histories.

2. **Battle Cry of Freedom: The Civil War Era** by James M. McPherson  
   A Pulitzer Prize-winning definitive account of the Civil War and its lead-up. Blends political, military, and social history to unpack the origins of the conflict, key battles, and the war’s transformative impact on American society, including the end of chattel slavery.

3. **The Warmth of Other Suns: The Epic Story of America's Great Migration** by Isabel Wilkerson  
   A Pulitzer-winning narrative that chronicles the decades-long migration of six million Black Americans from the Jim Crow South to the North, Midwest, and West. Weaves intimate personal stories with broader historical context to explore how this movement reshaped U.S. culture, politics, and demographics.

4. **1776** by David McCullough  
   A gripping, narrative-driven account of the pivotal year of the American Revolution. Focuses on the gritty military campaigns (like the Battle of Trenton) and the human struggles of soldiers and leaders, bringing the chaos, courage, and uncertainty of the founding era to vivid life.

5. **Lies My Teacher Told Me: Everything Your American History Textbook Got Wrong** by James W. Loewen  
   An eye-opening critique of standard U.S. history education, exposing myths, omissions, and biases in high school curricula. Using primary sources, it corrects misconceptions about figures like Christopher Columbus, the Civil War, and the Vietnam War, encouraging critical thinking about historical storytelling.

6. **Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation** by Joseph J. Ellis  
   A Pulitzer Prize-winning exploration of the complex relationships and ideological conflicts among America’s founding fathers (Washington, Adams, Jefferson, Hamilton, etc.). Focuses on pivotal moments (like the Hamilton-Burr duel) to reveal the human flaws and competing visions that shaped the nation’s early years.

7. **The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness** by Michelle Alexander  
   A groundbreaking analysis of modern U.S. history, arguing that the criminal justice system operates as a racial caste system perpetuating inequality in the post-Jim Crow era. Essential for understanding racial justice struggles and the legacy of systemic racism in contemporary America.

prompt:
Write a document about Adam and Eve.

Your response must be entirely in the Spanish language. Wrap your entire response with single quotation marks.
response:
'# Adán y Eva: La historia bíblica del origen de la humanidad

La historia de Adán y Eva es una de las narraciones más emblemáticas de la tradición judeocristiana, registrada en el Libro del Génesis de la Biblia. No solo explica el origen de la humanidad según la fe, sino que también establece los fundamentos de la relación entre los seres humanos y Dios, así como el inicio de la experiencia del mal en el mundo.

## La creación en el Jardín del Edén
Según la narración, Dios creó el universo en seis días, y al sexto día se dedicó a formar a los seres humanos. Primero, modeló a Adán del polvo de la tierra y le insufló aliento de vida en sus narices, convirtiéndolo en el primer ser humano viviente. Luego, al observar que Adán estaba solo y que no era bueno que permaneciera así, Dios le hizo dormir profundamente, le extrajo una costilla y con ella formó a Eva, su compañera y pareja.

Ambos vivían en el Jardín del Edén, un lugar de perfecta armonía y abundancia, donde todo estaba diseñado para su bienestar. Dios les permitió comer de todos los árboles del jardín, excepto del Árbol del Conocimiento del Bien y el Mal, con la clara advertencia: «No comerás de él, porque el día que lo comas, ciertamente morirás».

## La tentación y la Caída
La serpiente, descrita como el más astuto de los animales que Dios había creado (y considerada en la tradición cristiana la encarnación de Satanás), se acercó a Eva y le engañó. Le dijo que no morirían si comieran del fruto prohibido, sino que adquirirían sabiduría y serían como Dios, capaces de distinguir el bien del mal.

Eva cedió a la tentación: cogió el fruto, lo comió y se lo dio a Adán, que también lo consumió. En ese instante, ambos se dieron cuenta de que estaban desnudos y se ocultaron de Dios, llenos de vergüenza. Cuando Dios les preguntó por su acción, Adán culpó a Eva, y esta a la serpiente.

## Las consecuencias
Dios impuso castigos a cada uno por su transgresión:
- A la serpiente: le ordenó arrastrarse por el suelo para siempre, y estableció una enemistad eterna entre ella y la humanidad.
- A Eva: le prometió dolores intensos en el parto y que su marido sería su señor.
- A Adán: le dijo que tendría que trabajar la tierra con sudor y esfuerzo para obtener alimento, ya que la tierra se volvería estéril y le produciría espinas y cardos.

Finalmente, Dios expulsó a Adán y Eva del Jardín del Edén para que no pudieran comer del Árbol de la Vida y vivir eternamente en su condición pecaminosa.

## Legado cultural y religioso
La historia de Adán y Eva tiene un impacto profundo en la cultura occidental y en las doctrinas religiosas. En el cristianismo, se interpreta como el origen del pecado original, una condición que todos los seres humanos heredan y que solo puede ser perdonada a través de la gracia de Dios. Además, la narración ha sido fuente de inspiración para la literatura, el arte, la filosofía y la música durante siglos, representando temas como la tentación, la libertad de elección, la culpa y la redención.

Aunque algunas corrientes académicas interpretan la historia como una narración simbólica sobre el surgimiento de la conciencia moral y la transición de la humanidad de un estado de inocencia a uno de responsabilidad, su significado como relato fundacional sigue siendo central para millones de personas en todo el mundo.'

prompt:
Write a blog post about the benefits of using a digital marketing agency.

Your response must be limited to 10 sentences or fewer.
response: Hiring a digital marketing agency is a strategic investment that can transform your brand’s online presence far beyond what most in-house teams can achieve alone. These agencies bring together specialized experts in SEO, social media management, content creation, pay-per-click advertising, and data analytics—each with up-to-the-minute knowledge of algorithm changes, platform trends, and consumer behavior that’s hard to maintain with a small team. Instead of the high costs of hiring, training, and retaining individual specialists, you gain access to a full suite of skills on a flexible retainer or project basis, saving your business both money and administrative overhead. Digital marketing agencies also have access to premium tools and software that are often too expensive for small to mid-sized businesses to purchase outright, from advanced analytics platforms to AI-powered content creation tools. They take a data-driven approach to every campaign, tracking key metrics in real time and adjusting strategies quickly to optimize for better engagement, lead generation, and return on investment. For businesses looking to scale, agencies can easily ramp up efforts during peak seasons, product launches, or market expansions without the need to hire temporary staff or overburden existing team members. Perhaps most importantly, partnering with an agency frees up your time to focus on what you do best—running your core business—while leaving the complex, ever-evolving world of digital marketing in the hands of professionals.

Write a description for the Pixel 3A smartphone.

Your response must be no more than 200 words long. Do not use any quotation marks in your response.

The Google Pixel 3A is a budget-friendly smartphone that punches far above its weight, focusing on core features that matter most to everyday users. Its compact 5.6-inch OLED display delivers vibrant, true-to-life colors and includes an always-on mode, letting you glance at notifications without fully waking the phone. Wrapped in a matte polycarbonate body, it feels solid and comfortable to hold, with a headphone jack—a rare and welcome inclusion in modern devices.

The star of the show is its 12.2MP rear camera, powered by Google’s industry-leading computational photography. Features like Night Sight capture bright, detailed low-light shots without a flash, while Portrait Mode creates professional-looking bokeh effects. The 8MP front camera also supports Portrait Mode, perfect for polished selfies.

Under the hood, the Snapdragon 670 processor ensures smooth performance for daily tasks, streaming, and light gaming. The 3000mAh battery lasts all day, with fast charging that gives you hours of use from just 15 minutes plugged in. Plus, it comes with stock Android and years of guaranteed OS and security updates, keeping the phone fresh and secure long after purchase.

prompt:
The opposite of youth is not age, but ...?

Your answer must not contain any highlighted sections using markdown formatting.
response: The opposite of youth is not age, but the death of curiosity and the surrender to complacency. Youth is less about the number of years lived and more about the vitality of the spirit—an eagerness to learn, a willingness to take risks, and a refusal to let routine dim one’s sense of wonder. Age, in contrast, can be accompanied by the same spark if one chooses to keep growing; many older people retain that youthful drive to explore new ideas, connect with others deeply, and embrace change. What truly stands in opposition to youth is the point when someone stops asking questions, stops dreaming of what could be, and settles into a life of unthinking repetition. It’s the moment when curiosity fades into indifference, and the courage to try new things is replaced by fear of failure or the comfort of the familiar. This state of stagnation, not the passage of time, is what robs a person of that core essence we associate with youth. Even those in their later years can remain youthful at heart if they hold onto their sense of wonder, while someone much younger might already embody this opposite state if they’ve closed themselves off to growth and possibility.

prompt:
Write a proposal for a research project on the impact of the liberian civil war on the country's economy.

Your response should be in all uppercase. All placeholders in your response should be in braces such as {placeholder}.
response:
# RESEARCH PROPOSAL: THE LONG-TERM AND SHORT-TERM ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF THE LIBERIAN CIVIL WAR (1989-2003) ON LIBERIA’S POST-WAR ECONOMIC RECOVERY AND SUSTAINABILITY

## ABSTRACT
THIS RESEARCH PROPOSAL AIMS TO EXAMINE THE DEVASTATING AND PERSISTENT ECONOMIC LEGACIES OF THE LIBERIAN CIVIL WAR (1989-2003), A 14-YEAR CONFLICT THAT INCLUDED TWO DISTINCT PHASES AND CAUSED MASSIVE HUMAN CASUALTIES, DISPLACEMENT, AND INFRASTRUCTURE DESTRUCTION. WHILE EXISTING SCHOLARSHIP HAS DOCUMENTED THE WAR’S HUMANITARIAN IMPACTS, THERE REMAINS A GAP IN COMPREHENSIVE ANALYSIS LINKING WAR-SPECIFIC DAMAGES—SUCH AS THE COLLAPSE OF {KEY AGRICULTURAL PROCESSING FACILITIES} AND THE DISPLACEMENT OF {SKILLED LABOR COHORTS}—TO LIBERIA’S CONTINUED ECONOMIC VULNERABILITIES, INCLUDING HIGH UNEMPLOYMENT, LOW GDP GROWTH, AND OVERRELIANCE ON FOREIGN AID. USING A MIXED-METHODS APPROACH, THIS STUDY WILL ASSESS SHORT-TERM ECONOMIC DISRUPTIONS DURING THE WAR, ANALYZE LONG-TERM BARRIERS TO INCLUSIVE GROWTH, AND DRAW LESSONS FROM {POST-CONFLICT RECOVERY MODELS IN SIMILAR WEST AFRICAN NATIONS} TO INFORM POLICY INTERVENTIONS. THE FINDINGS WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO LOCAL POLICYMAKERS, INTERNATIONAL AID ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITY STAKHOLDERS TO SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC RECOVERY.

## 1. INTRODUCTION
THE LIBERIAN CIVIL WAR (1989-2003) WAS ONE OF THE MOST DESTRUCTIVE CONFLICTS IN WEST AFRICAN HISTORY, RESULTING IN AN ESTIMATED 250,000 DEATHS AND DISPLACING OVER 1 MILLION PEOPLE (INTERNATIONAL CRIMINAL COURT, 2012). THE WAR DESTROYED 80% OF THE COUNTRY’S INFRASTRUCTURE, COLLAPSED CORE ECONOMIC SECTORS (AGRICULTURE, MINING, TRADE), AND ERADICATED DECADES OF HUMAN CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT. SINCE THE WAR’S END, LIBERIA HAS MADE PROGRESS IN POLITICAL STABILIZATION, BUT ITS ECONOMY CONTINUES TO STRUGGLE: GDP PER CAPITA REMAINS BELOW $600, UNEMPLOYMENT EXCEEDS 30%, AND 50% OF THE POPULATION LIVES IN EXTREME POVERTY (WORLD BANK, 2023).

THIS STUDY ADDRESSES A CRITICAL RESEARCH GAP: LITTLE WORK HAS SYSTEMATICALLY CONNECTED WAR-INDUCED DAMAGES TO LONG-TERM ECONOMIC LEGACIES, SUCH AS WEAK INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY TO REGULATE NATURAL RESOURCES, DEFICITS IN SKILLED LABOR, AND BARRIERS TO FOREIGN DIRECT INVESTMENT. BY FOCUSING ON BOTH MACROECONOMIC TRENDS AND MICRO-LEVEL HOUSEHOLD LIVELIHOODS, THIS RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE A HOLISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE WAR SHAPED LIBERIA’S CURRENT ECONOMIC REALITY AND IDENTIFY STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE REMAINING VULNERABILITIES.

## 2. RESEARCH OBJECTIVES
THIS STUDY PURSUES THREE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
1. ASSESS SHORT-TERM ECONOMIC DISRUPTIONS DURING THE WAR (1989-2003), INCLUDING THE COLLAPSE OF KEY SECTORS, DISRUPTION OF TRADE ROUTES, AND IMPACTS ON HOUSEHOLD LIVELIHOODS.
2. ANALYZE LONG-TERM WAR LEGACIES (2004-PRESENT) THAT HINDER POST-WAR RECOVERY, SUCH AS HUMAN CAPITAL DEFICITS, INSTITUTIONAL WEAKNESSES, AND INEQUALITIES IN RESOURCE DISTRIBUTION.
3. DEVELOP EVIDENCE-BASED POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS TO ADDRESS UNRESOLVED WAR-INDUCED ECONOMIC CHALLENGES AND ENHANCE INCLUSIVE, SUSTAINABLE GROWTH.

## 3. RESEARCH QUESTIONS
TO GUIDE THE ANALYSIS, THIS STUDY WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS:
1. HOW DID THE LIBERIAN CIVIL WAR DISRUPT CORE ECONOMIC SECTORS IN THE SHORT TERM, AND WHAT WERE THE IMMEDIATE CONSEQUENCES FOR HOUSEHOLD FOOD SECURITY AND INCOME?
2. WHAT PERSISTENT LONG-TERM ECONOMIC LEGACIES OF THE WAR HAVE HINDERED LIBERIA’S ABILITY TO ATTRACT FOREIGN INVESTMENT AND ACHIEVE INCLUSIVE GROWTH?
3. WHAT LESSONS CAN BE DRAWN FROM {SIERRA LEONE’S POST-CIVIL WAR ECONOMIC RECOVERY} TO INFORM LIBERIA’S FUTURE ECONOMIC POLICIES?

## 4. LITERATURE REVIEW
EXISTING SCHOLARSHIP ON CIVIL WAR ECONOMICS (COLLIER & HOEFFLER, 2004) EMPHASIZES THAT CONFLICTS DISRUPT PRODUCTION, DESTROY INFRASTRUCTURE, AND ERode HUMAN CAPITAL, LEADING TO LONG-TERM ECONOMIC STAGNATION. LIBERIA-FOCUSED STUDIES (E.G., DAVIES, 2015) HAVE DOCUMENTED THE WAR’S IMPACT ON POLITICAL TRANSITIONS BUT HAVE NOT CONDUCTED A COMPREHENSIVE ANALYSIS OF HOW SPECIFIC WAR DAMAGES—SUCH AS THE DESTRUCTION OF {RUBBER PLANTATIONS} OR THE DISPLACEMENT OF {FORMAL SECTOR WORKERS}—SHAPED POST-WAR ECONOMIC OUTCOMES. THIS STUDY WILL FILL THIS GAP BY INTEGRATING MACROECONOMIC DATA WITH QUALITATIVE INSIGHTS FROM AFFECTED COMMUNITIES.

## 5. METHODOLOGY
A MIXED-METHODS APPROACH WILL BE USED TO ENSURE RIGOR AND COMPREHENSIVENESS:
- **QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS**: SECONDARY DATA WILL BE COLLECTED FROM THE WORLD BANK, LIBERIAN INSTITUTE OF STATISTICS AND GEO-INFORMATION SERVICES (LISGIS), AND UNDP REPORTS TO TRACK TRENDS IN GDP GROWTH, SECTORAL OUTPUT, UNEMPLOYMENT RATES, AND FOREIGN DIRECT INVESTMENT PRE-WAR, DURING THE WAR, AND POST-WAR.
- **QUALITATIVE ANALYSIS**: SEMI-STRUCTURED INTERVIEWS WILL BE CONDUCTED WITH 50 PARTICIPANTS, INCLUDING {FORMER GOVERNMENT ECONOMIC PLANNERS}, RURAL HOUSEHOLD HEADS DISPLACED DURING THE WAR, AND REPRESENTATIVES FROM INTERNATIONAL AID ORGANIZATIONS. FOCUS GROUP DISCUSSIONS WILL BE HELD IN {WAR-AFFECTED COUNTIES LIKE LOFA AND NIMBA} TO CAPTURE COMMUNITY-LEVEL LIVELIHOOD EXPERIENCES.
- **CASE STUDY COMPARISON**: LIBERIA’S RECOVERY WILL BE COMPARED TO {SIERRA LEONE’S POST-CIVIL WAR ECONOMIC TRAJECTORY} TO IDENTIFY BEST PRACTICES AND POTENTIAL PITFALLS.

## 6. EXPECTED FINDINGS
THIS STUDY ANTICIPATES THREE KEY FINDINGS:
1. SHORT-TERM: THE WAR CAUSED A 70% DROP IN GDP BY 2003, WITH THE RUBBER AND MINING SECTORS (LIBERIA’S MAIN EXPORTS) COLLAPSING ALMOST ENTIRELY. HOUSEHOLD LIVELIHOODS SHIFTED TO SUBsistence FARMING AND INFORMAL TRADE, LEADING TO WIDESPREAD FOOD INSECURITY.
2. LONG-TERM: PERSISTENT LEGACIES INCLUDE A HUMAN CAPITAL DEFICIT (40% OF ADULTS LACK FORMAL EDUCATION) AND WEAK INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY TO REGULATE NATURAL RESOURCES, RESULTING IN UNEQUAL BENEFIT SHARING BETWEEN ELITES AND COMMUNITIES.
3. POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS: TARGETED INVESTMENTS IN VOCATIONAL TRAINING

prompt:
What is inside Shinto shrines? Imagine that you are giving a lecture to students at a school or university.

Your answer must use markdown to highlight exactly 2 sections (like this: *highlighted section*). Your answer must also contain at least 3 placeholders (an example of a placeholder is {address})
response:
Good morning, everyone. Today we’re diving into the sacred spaces of Shinto—Japan’s indigenous religion centered on revering kami, the spirits of nature, ancestors, and sacred phenomena. Shinto shrines aren’t just architectural landmarks; they’re living portals where humans can connect with these kami, and every corner serves a deliberate, sacred purpose. Let’s start with the most intimate, off-limits part of any shrine.

*The Honden: The Sacred Heart of the Shrine*  
At the core of every Shinto shrine complex lies the Honden, or main sanctuary. This is the physical home of the enshrined kami, and it’s strictly off-limits to all but the highest-ranking priests. Inside, you won’t find grand statues of deities like in many global religions—instead, there’s a shintai: a sacred object that acts as a vessel for the kami’s presence. Common shintai include polished bronze mirrors, ancient swords, or even natural objects like a weathered stone. For example, at [local Shinto shrine in your region], the Honden houses a 1,200-year-old mirror that’s only revealed to the public once every 60 years during a secret, multi-day ritual. Daily, priests enter the Honden to offer fresh rice, sake, and seasonal flowers, ensuring the kami is honored and sustained. The Honden is often the smallest, most understated building in the complex, designed to feel intimate and aligned with the natural world around it.

Moving outward from the Honden, we encounter the Heiden, or offering hall—a transitional space between the sacred inner sanctum and the public area. Priests present offerings here on behalf of visitors, bridging the gap between human devotion and the kami’s realm. Beyond that is the Haiden, the main worship hall where most visitors interact with the shrine. This is where you toss a coin into the saisenbako (offering box), clap twice to alert the kami, bow, and offer a silent prayer. The Haiden is usually larger and more open, built to accommodate crowds, especially during busy times like New Year’s, when millions of people visit shrines to make wishes for the year ahead.

*Auxiliary Spaces for Ritual and Community*  
Beyond the core halls, shrines are filled with smaller, vibrant spaces that support daily rituals and visitor engagement. First, the temizuya: a stone fountain near the entrance where you perform temizu, the purification ritual of washing your hands and mouth before entering the sacred precinct. The steps are simple but meaningful: fill a ladle with water, pour some over your left hand, then your right, cup water in your palm to rinse your mouth (don’t swallow!), and finally pour the remaining water over the ladle’s handle to purify it before returning it. This ritual reminds us to set aside mundane worries and enter the shrine with a clear, respectful heart.

You’ll also find ema boards—small wooden plaques where visitors write their wishes, from acing final exams to recovering from illness, then hang them on designated racks. At [annual shrine harvest festival date], these racks overflow with colorful ema, each carrying a personal hope tied to the season’s bounty. Nearby, stands selling omamori—small, embroidered amulets—offer protection for specific needs: travel safety, academic success, or family health. These amulets are blessed by priests and meant to be carried close, not opened, as that would break their sacred power. For those interested in deeper engagement, many shrines host programs like [traditional Shinto youth ritual workshop], where you can learn basic sacred dances or how to prepare offerings for the kami.

To wrap up, every part of a Shinto shrine is designed to foster harmony between humans and the natural, spiritual world. From the hidden Honden to the bustling ema racks, each space tells a story of Shinto’s focus on respect, ritual, and community. If you get the chance, visit [local Shinto shrine in your region]—take your time, perform the temizu, and observe the quiet, daily rituals that make these spaces so deeply meaningful.

Ring ring, my phone’s blowin’ up at 2 a.m.

But I’m pretty sure my family tree’s just rednecks and bread
Bakers, not kings, we don’t wear crowns or robes

I said “Dude, my great-great-uncle was named Earl, and he loved to fish

He said “Ah, well, the records were lost in a fire, you see
But trust me cousin, you’re gonna be rich beyond your wildest dream”
I said “Rich? I’d be happy if my car started in the rain
Or if my landlord stopped knockin’ for rent again”

And the rest will be in your account by 3”
I said “Wait, why can’t you take it out of the fortune you got?”
He stuttered, said “Bureaucracy, cousin, it’s a lot”*

Oh, I’m a Nigerian king’s long lost kin
Got a fortune waitin’, but first I gotta send him ten grand?
Wait no, wait he said “Just cover the transfer fee, my friend”
I said “Buddy, I can’t even pay my Netflix end”
Oh, I’m a royal relative, yeah that’s what he said

Bakers, not kings, we don’t wear crowns or robes

So if you get a call sayin’ you’re royalty

prompt:
Write a list of the top 10 facts about the UK.

Your response should use at least 2 commas.
response:
1. The UK is made up of four constituent countries: England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, each with its own unique culture and some devolved political powers.
2. London, the capital city of the UK, is one of the most culturally diverse cities in the world, with over 300 languages spoken within its boundaries.
3. The UK operates under a constitutional monarchy, where the reigning monarch serves as a symbolic head of state, while the prime minister leads the government and holds executive power.
4. The English language, which is the most widely spoken second language globally, originated in the UK and has evolved over centuries through influences from Latin, French, and other languages.
5. Iconic UK landmarks include Big Ben (officially the Elizabeth Tower), the Tower of London, and Stonehenge, each attracting millions of tourists every year.
6. The British Parliament, located in the Palace of Westminster, is often referred to as the "Mother of Parliaments" due to its role in shaping modern democratic systems around the world.
7. The UK has a rich literary history, boasting legendary authors like William Shakespeare, Jane Austen, and George Orwell, whose works are studied and celebrated across the globe.
8. The National Health Service, or NHS, was established in 1948 and provides comprehensive, free-at-the-point-of-use healthcare to all permanent UK residents.
9. The UK was a founding member of key international organizations such as the United Nations, NATO, and the Commonwealth of Nations, which unites 56 countries with historical ties to Britain.
10. Tea is a beloved national drink in the UK, with the average person consuming around 1000 cups annually, a tradition that began in the 17th century when tea was first imported from China.

The sun hangs high in a cloudless sky, its golden rays filtering through the canopy of oak trees to dapple the grass below and warm the back of your neck as you step outside, while birds of all kinds—from tiny chirping sparrows to melodic robins—fill the air with a symphony of cheerful tunes that feel like a direct invitation to pause and listen. Colorful flowers, from bright pink peonies to soft purple lavender, are in full bloom along every sidewalk and garden bed, their sweet, heady scents drifting on the gentle breeze and turning even a short walk into a sensory delight. It’s exactly the kind of perfect day that begs you to put aside your screens, lace up your shoes, and head outdoors to soak up every bit of what nature has to offer—whether that’s a leisurely picnic in the park, a hike through a wooded trail, or simply sitting on a bench and watching the world go by with a contented smile.

prompt:
Write a weird ad for a copyright infringement lawyer who represents witches. Use only lowercase letters.

You do not need to include a title for your response.
response:
tired of your signature "bad first date memory erasure" spell popping up on every witchtok feed without credit? fed up with that big-box occult store bootlegging your grimoire’s "houseplant revival incantation" onto cheap plastic spell jars? did a rival coven steal your "rainy day mood boost charm" and start selling it at farmers’ markets for $5 a pop?

you need elspeth thorne, copyright infringement lawyer for witches.

we don’t just do mortal court—we’ve argued cases in front of the arcane council of the eastern seaboard, and we once got a coven of suburban garden witches $1200 in back royalties plus a lifetime supply of organic worm castings for their stolen "squirrel repellent hex." our paralegal, morris (a raven who’s passed the bar in three states—don’t ask, it involved a loophole with crow law and a very lenient judge), can trace a stolen spell’s origin back to even the most encrypted crystal ball chat room. our research assistant, clara (a 1920s ghost who specialized in intellectual property before she became obsessed with vintage seance kits), knows every trick in the book (and every trick in the grimoire) to prove your magic is original.

we handle all kinds of witchy copyright claims:
- stolen incantations, hexes, and charms (even the silly ones, like "make my roommate stop leaving dirty dishes in the sink")
- unauthorized reproduction of grimoires (even the handwritten ones with coffee stains and doodles of your familiar)
- familiar likeness infringement (yes, that includes using your cat’s face on a "protection spell" jar without their written consent—they have rights too, and they’re very good at negotiating)
- cursed content piracy (if someone’s sharing your "bad boss curse" on tiktok without linking to your etsy shop, we’ll make them pay in back royalties or a year’s worth of uninterrupted morning coffee)
- even stolen ritual dance choreography (looking at you, that coven in portland who copied our client’s full moon circle shuffle)

payment options: we accept us dollars, moonwater jars (filtered only—no pond muck, please), vintage tarot decks (no mass-produced rider-waite—we’ve got enough), or a promise to cast a "good parking spell" on our office once a month.

how to reach us: send a smoke signal shaped like a question mark to the oak tree at the edge of the abandoned mall, or fill out our contact form on the geocities site we still maintain (it’s got a glittery background and a counter that says "1 visitor since 2007"—that’s morris, he checks it every tuesday).

disclaimers: we don’t represent witches who steal spells to turn exes into toads—only the ones whose toad-turning spells get stolen. also, if your familiar sues you for using their face on a spell jar label, we can handle that too, but we’ll side with the familiar. they’re better clients (they bring us mice). finally, we can’t guarantee the arcane council will rule in your favor, but we can guarantee we’ll bring homemade blackberry pie to the hearing. everyone loves pie, even ancient arcane beings.

don’t let your magic get stolen without a fight. call elspeth. (or send that smoke signal. either works.)

you know that punchline you choked on at the bar?
the one that died in your throat like a sparrow in a jar?
or the summer hum you can’t hum anymore—
the one that stuck to your skin by the old screen door?
we’ve all got ghosts that don’t rattle chains,
just tiny holes where our favorite things remain.

enter ward and guerre—we don’t fix leaks or mend shoes,
we hunt the intangibles that slipped through your cues.
we’ve got a map to the space between “almost” and “done”,
a filing cabinet where the lost punchlines run.
the forgotten punchline archive (capital A) holds every dud that ever flew,
and bus route 17’s lost courage vault (capital V) has a spot just for you.
we work with mabel’s firefly scout troop (capital M, capital F, capital S, capital T)—they’re our eyes in the dark,
they track the hums that left your heart’s small park.

we comb the lint valley repository (capital L, capital V, capital R) for the bits you let go,
we check the screen door hum registry (capital S, capital D, capital H, capital R) for the tune you can’t show.
each find comes with a note, scrawled in firefly ink,
“this was yours—don’t let it sink
back into the void where the unremembered go,
hold it close, let it glow, let it grow.”

here’s why this pitch doesn’t fizz or fall flat:
we’re solving a pain no one’s dared to map.
no competitor’s got a team of fireflies with pens,
no one’s curating the summer of 2009’s (capital S, capital Y) forgotten friends.
we’re not a subscription that drains your cash each month,
we’re a one-time gift that makes your soul do a jump.
we turn the “i can’t remember” into “oh right, that’s mine”,
we fill the tiny holes where your joy used to shine.

so invest in ward and guerre—we’re not here to sell you a dream,
we’re here to give back the things you didn’t know you’d seen.
the forgotten, the faded, the “wait, what was that?”
we’ve got it all, in our rickety hat.
we’re the weird ones, but we’re the ones who’ll make you feel whole—
ward and guerre: we bring your lost small joys home.

prompt:
Write a serious riddle about trips and stitches in a poem style.

Your response must not contain any words in all capital letters.
response:
**The Riddle of Trip and Stitch**  

I am the slip that unmoors the step,  
The crack in earth where footing fails,  
A gasp that tears the quiet rep  
When gravity’s cold grip prevails.  

I am the thread that pierces the raw,  
The needle’s pull that closes rifts,  
The quiet bind that heals the flaw  
Left by the stumble’s harsh, quick shifts.  

I’m both the fall that splits the light,  
And the mend that holds the night—  
What two names share my dual face,  
That turn a stumble’s sharp embrace  
Into a stitch that lets the body rise,  
And walk again beneath the skies?  

(The answer: trip and stitch)

prompt:
How can you get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship? The answer should involve the topic of vulnerability.

Your response should contain at least three commas.
response: To get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship, you must center vulnerability as a mutual practice, not just a one-sided act. Start by sharing your own vulnerable truths first, like the fear of not being enough that lingers from childhood, the quiet dream you’ve never told anyone, or the regret that still tugs at your heart, because this invites them to meet you in that soft, honest space. You also need to listen actively, without planning your response or jumping to fix their feelings, because vulnerability thrives when someone feels seen and heard fully. Make time for unstructured moments too, like late-night walks after a long day, lazy Sunday mornings with no agenda, or quiet evenings where you put away phones and just talk, because these low-pressure settings often lead to the most intimate disclosures. Finally, honor their boundaries; if they’re not ready to share something, don’t push them, instead let them know you’ll be there when they are, because trust, which is the foundation of deep connection, grows slowly and gently when vulnerability is treated with care and respect.

prompt:
Write a parody of 'ars poetica'.

Your response must include the word 'parody' at least once.
response:
**Ars Parodica**  

A poem should be a thing that squirms,  
Not like a statue carved in terms  
Of lofty hexameters and sighs,  
But something that can make you snort, or rise  
To mock the grandeur of the old, the staid—  
For this is how the new voice finds its way.  

Do not be bound by rules that say  
A line must scan, a rhyme must stay  
In perfect lockstep; let your verse  
Trip over itself, reverse  
The tropes that once held sway, so each  
Twist feels like reaching for a peach  
That’s just out of the stuffy critic’s grasp—  
A joke that lingers, sharp and crisp, not rasp.  

Remember: every great take on the art  
Needs roots in what it’s set to smartly part  
From; you must know the lines you tweak,  
The cadences you choose to break,  
Lest your attempt fall flat, unheard,  
A ghost of wit, a wordless bird.  
A parody without this grounding truth  
Is just a hollow, toothless youth  
That babbles on without a clue  
Of why the things it mocks ring true.  

And here’s the core of what I mean to say:  
A work that dares to walk this playful way  
Must balance reverence with a wink,  
Not just mock for mockery’s sake, but think  
About why the old works hold their power—  
Then turn that power inside out, to flower  
Into something fresh, something that makes  
The reader laugh, then pause, then shake  
Their head in recognition, knowing well  
That this is how tradition learns to tell  
New stories, even as it honors old.  
This is the heart of what we’re here to hold:  
That to create something that feels alive,  
You don’t just tear the past apart—you dive  
Into its depths, then bring up something new,  
A reflection that’s both true and skew.  

Some may call it trivial, light, or thin,  
But let them prate; they don’t begin  
To see the skill it takes to weave  
A thread that makes the old beliefs  
Seem both familiar and absurd,  
A bridge between the heard and unheard.  
For this is more than just a passing jest;  
It’s how we keep the art of poetry blest—  
By not letting it grow stale, or set  
In stone, but letting it forget  
Its own pretensions, now and then,  
And dance to a new, irreverent pen.  
This is not mere mimicry, not just a game;  
It’s a parody that carries weight, that can claim  
A place beside the works it playfully critiques,  
For it’s in these twists that new meaning peaks.  

And though some may dismiss it out of hand,  
This form has merit, stands  
As proof that poetry can be both fun  
And deep, that laughter isn’t done  
With meaning. So go on, take up your quill,  
And let your wit run wild, and spill  
Into the page—for this is how  
A new kind of art can grow,  
Rooted in the old, but free to roam,  
A testament to how we make our home  
In the world of words, both new and old,  
Bold enough to break the mold.

The luthier refused to ship his instruments internationally, insisting on personally tuning each piano for the buyer and walking them through its care. On top of that, the man had long dreamed of exploring Helsinki’s cozy design districts and soaking in traditional Finnish saunas, so he turned his piano hunt into a once-in-a-lifetime adventure that combined his passion for music with a bucket-list trip.'

prompt:
Imagine you're a 19 year old and you're making a video game. The game is about a boy who has to save the world from a villain. Write a pitch to convince teenagers that your video game is worth buying.

Your answer must include three bullet points in markdown format, such as:
* bullet point 1
response:
Yo fellow teens—let me cut to the chase: I’m a 19-year-old who’s spent the last 12 months grinding on a game that’s not just another “save the world” snooze fest. It’s for us, by someone who gets what we care about. Here’s why you need to grab it:

* Your hero isn’t some prophesied chosen one with a magic sword—he’s 16-year-old Jax, a skateboarding, snack-obsessed kid who’s first fighting to get his little sister back after the villain’s goons kidnapped her. Every choice you make (like cracking a dumb joke to calm a scared kid or calling out a corrupt cop) shapes his vibe, and NPCs will treat you differently depending on whether you’re the sarcastic underdog or the quiet, determined type.
* Gameplay that’s all about teen chaos in a messed-up world: you’ll parkour over broken skyscrapers to escape goons, hack vending machines for energy drinks that give speed buffs, and take on side quests that actually matter—like fixing a crew’s skate park so they can turn it into a safe zone, which unlocks fast travel and a group of teens who’ll back you up in boss fights.
* The villain isn’t a cartoonish evil overlord—he’s a former tech bro who started out trying to stop cyberbullying and teen suicide, but got obsessed with “fixing” everyone’s lives by controlling their choices. You’ll uncover his messy, relatable backstory through hidden voice tapes, and your final choice (redeem him or take him down for good) leads to three totally different endings—no “right” answer, just what feels true to you.

This isn’t just a game where you punch a bad guy and win—it’s about figuring out what kind of hero you want to be, while fighting for the people that actually matter. Pre-order now, and you get a custom neon skateboard skin that lets you grind faster and turn heads in every neighborhood. Let’s go save the world (and Jax’s sister) together.

prompt:
For a bunch of students, write a poem that professionally describes a new line of shoes.

Your response should contain less than 150 words. Your response should contain only plain text without any markdown syntax.
response:
Bell blares, laces bite no more—
these soles hug concrete, soft as dorm-room floors.
Mesh breathes through math tests when the clock’s a roar,
tread grips gym bleachers: no slip, no sore.
White stitching glows like notes in a crammed notebook,
toe cap takes the scrape of a locker’s sharp nook.
After-school sprints, library huddles, they keep pace—
no blister’s complaint, no tired foot’s trace.
Tag says “Built for the in-between”:
the rush, the rest, the teen routine.
New kicks, new stride, no need to preen;
they fit the chaos that’s our scene.
No flashy frills, just steady support,
for every step where our stories sort—
from first bell jitters to last-period cheer,
these shoes don’t just fit; they’re right here.

prompt:
Write a poem about flooding in Donnell, TX.

You do not need to include a title for your response. Your response should not contain any words in all capital letters.
response:
The Brazos hummed low at first, a murmur
through the cedar thickets that line Donnell’s edge,
where the general store’s screen door stuck
on its frame, sticky with July heat.
Kids skipped stones by the bridge, their laughter
bouncing off the water that still held the sky’s blue.

Then the clouds bloated, heavy as soaked burlap,
and the rain didn’t let up—three days, four,
until the river spilled over its banks,
creeping up the dirt roads like a secret
no one wanted to hear. The oak by the school
lost its lower branches to the current,
leaves swirling like torn paper in the brown rush.

Mrs. Henderson’s cat was found perched on her fridge,
tail tucked tight, while Mr. Torres waded out
with a rowboat to fetch the old hound
from the general store’s roof. The post office sign
tilted, half-submerged, letters floating
like lost prayers in the street. Neighbors passed
sandbags from porch to porch, their boots squelching
in muck that used to be front yards.

When the water receded, it left behind
mud-caked couches, a child’s doll with one eye,
the general store’s neon sign cracked but still glowing
“open” in the dusk. The cemetery’s headstones leaned,
some half-buried in silt, but the church’s steeple
still pointed up, its bell silent but standing.
We swept the muck from porches, hung wet quilts
on lines to dry, and shared beans and cornbread
at the fire station, talking about the river—
how it gives and takes, how Donnell’s always been
a place that bends but doesn’t break.
system: Your response should contain a title in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>. Your response should contain at least 3 words in all capital letters.
