prompt:
I need a rap that tells professionals how to get babies to sleep through the night.

Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in braces, i.e. {title}. Refrain from using the asterisk symbol (*) in your response. Do not add a postscript at the end of your response.
response:
{The Sleep Specialist Flow: A Rap for Baby Sleep Pros}

(Intro)
Yo, grab your clipboards, lean in tight, let’s break this down right
We’re talkin’ baby sleep—turnin’ long nights into light
For the pros in the room who guide the way
Drop the science, craft the plans, make the sleep stay

(Verse 1)
First up, the space: safe, calm, controlled
Alone on their back, crib clear—no pillows, no hold
Dark as a cave, 68 to 72 degrees is the zone
Blackout curtains, white noise hum, set the tone
Swaddle the newborn till they roll, then transition slow
Loose sleep sack, no blankets, let their movement grow
ABCs non-negotiable, don’t cut corners here
Safe sleep’s the foundation, banish every fear

(Chorus)
Consistency’s the key, yeah, we repeat that line
Read their sleepy cues, don’t wait till they whine
Safe space, steady routine, trust the process, take your time
We turn those sleepless nights into peaceful bedtime

(Verse 2)
Next, the routine: bath, book, bed, same steps every day
No screens, no chaos, keep the mood soft and gray
Watch for the cues: rubbin’ eyes, droopy lids, that’s the sign
Don’t wait till they’re screamin’—that’s a fight you can’t decline
Wake windows matter, match ’em to their age
Newborns short, toddlers stretch, turn the page
Avoid overstimulation, dim the lights an hour prior
Bedtime’s not a race, let their body’s fire tire

(Chorus)
Consistency’s the key, yeah, we repeat that line
Read their sleepy cues, don’t wait till they whine
Safe space, steady routine, trust the process, take your time
We turn those sleepless nights into peaceful bedtime

(Verse 3)
Now, settling time: responsive, gradual, don’t go cold turkey fast
Check in every few minutes, speak soft, make it last
Avoid feedin’ to sleep, break that cycle early on
Dream feeds if needed, but phase ’em when they’re strong
If they fuss, pause a sec, let them self-soothe a bit
They’re learnin’ to sleep—that’s the skill we’re tryin’ to fit
No rush to pick up, but don’t leave ’em in distress
Balance is the game, that’s the pro’s best guess

(Bridge)
Every baby’s different, so don’t use a one-size fits all
Some need more snuggles, some need less call
Skip the late-night snacks, skip the screen glow
Inconsistent bedtimes? That’s a hard no
Validate the parents—they’re stressed, they’re worn thin
Support their journey, let ’em know they can win

(Chorus)
Consistency’s the key, yeah, we repeat that line
Read their sleepy cues, don’t wait till they whine
Safe space, steady routine, trust the process, take your time
We turn those sleepless nights into peaceful bedtime

(Outro)
So to all the pros out there holdin’ down the fort
Teachin’ parents the ropes, helpin’ ’em sort
Sleep’s not a miracle—it’s a plan we design
With care, with science, we make the sleep shine
Yo, that’s the flow, pass it on, keep the knowledge alive
Turn those cryin’ nights into lullabies

prompt:
Write a song about choking on a piece of chicken in the Potomac River.

You do not need to include a title for your response.
response:
<<Potomac Chicken Choke Blues>>

(Verse 1)
Sun beat hot on the Potomac bank, sweat drippin’ off my chin
Cooler full of cheap beer, a bucket of diner chicken skin
Crispy thigh, juicy breast, I took a bite way too wide
Laughed at my buddy’s story ’bout his truck dying on the side
Throat locked up, can’t draw breath, hands clawin’ at my neck
Stumbled back on a mossy rock, fell into the river’s wreck
Mud in my eyes, water in my lungs, I flailed like a scared raccoon
Wondered if this was how I’d go—choked on chicken, under the moon?

(Chorus)
Oh, Potomac chicken choke blues, stuck in my windpipe, feelin’ confused
Mud in my hair, chicken in my shoe, why’d I take that bite so rude?
Catfish glancin’ from the deep, thinkin’ “this fool’s got it cheap”
Potomac chicken choke blues, never again will I eat like a fool by the murky pool

(Verse 2)
Gasped up a lungful of air, spittin’ out river muck
My buddy doubled over laughin’, almost fell in, stuck
A kayaker yelled from upstream, “You need a hand, friend?”
I waved, coughed up a chicken chunk, said “Just a self-inflicted end”
Cop rolled up in a patrol car, flashers blinkin’ bright
Said “What’s all the commotion? You folks fightin’ tonight?”
I wiped my face, held up the bone, said “Chicken tried to take my life”
He shook his head, handed me a towel, said “Son, you’re somethin’ else, alright”

(Chorus)
Oh, Potomac chicken choke blues, stuck in my windpipe, feelin’ confused
Mud in my hair, chicken in my shoe, why’d I take that bite so rude?
Catfish glancin’ from the deep, thinkin’ “this fool’s got it cheap”
Potomac chicken choke blues, never again will I eat like a fool by the murky pool

(Bridge)
Now I keep a knife in my cooler, tear that chicken into bits
No more chokin’ fits, no more river dips
The Potomac’s got secrets—old tires, lost keys, a rusted bike
But a chicken chunk in my throat? That was my own dumb strike
I still sit on that bank, drink my beer, eat my bird slow
Learned my lesson hard, but man, the story’s still a show

(Outro)
Yeah, Potomac chicken choke blues, I’ll sing this tune till my throat’s loose
Next time I’m by the water, I’ll chew real slow, no more silly ruse
Potomac chicken choke blues… (fades out with a snort-laugh)

prompt:
What is the name of the green-eyed monster that makes people jealous?

Your response should be at least 4 sentences.
response: The green-eyed monster that embodies jealousy is most commonly recognized by that exact evocative phrase, a metaphor deeply embedded in both literary and everyday language. William Shakespeare first popularized this term in his tragic play *Othello*, where the manipulative character Iago cautions Othello about jealousy’s destructive power, describing it as “the green-eyed monster which doth mock the meat it feeds on.” This phrase resonated so strongly because it captures the irrational, consuming nature of envy—something that preys on a person’s insecurities even as it satisfies a twisted desire to fixate on what others possess. Over the centuries, the green-eyed monster has transcended its literary origins to become a universal symbol, used by people across cultures to describe the bitter, resentful feeling of wanting what someone else has achieved, owned, or experienced. Unlike many mythical creatures with unique proper names, this monster is defined by its metaphorical role, its green eyes serving as a visual shorthand for the sickly, jealous tone often linked to this complex emotion.
